THIS PROPOSAL IS TO FUND THE U-ACRE (URBAN AGRICULTURE COMMUNITY-BASED RESEARCH EXPERIENCE) PROJECT AT CALIFORNIA STATE UNIVERSITY, FULLERTON (CSUF) WITH SEVERAL INNOVATIONS BASED ON PROGRESS SINCE THE PROJECT'S INCEPTION. THESE INCLUDE DEEPENING OF THE STUDENT EXPERIENCE THROUGH INTEGRATION WITH ONGOING COMMUNITY-BASED RESEARCH ACTIVITIES, AND ADDITIONAL EMPHASIS ON DEVELOPING INNOVATION AND LEADERSHIP CAPABILITIES RELATED TO THE FANH SCIENCES. THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE APPROXIMATELY 300 SERVICE-LEARNING STUDENTS PER YEAR. THE PROJECT PARTNERS INCLUDE FOUR K-12 SCHOOLS; NON-PROFITS SERVING THE HUNGRY, HOMELESS, AND FOSTER YOUTH; AND AREA FARMS. WITH THESE PARTNERS WE PLAN AND MANAGE COMMUNITY AND SCHOOL GARDENS AND WASTE DIVERSION USING VERMICOMPOST AND THERMOPHILIC COMPOST, AND CONDUCT RESEARCH ON NUTRITION AND DIETARY CHOICES, FOOD SECURITY AMONG THE HOUSING INSECURE, TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE, INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT, AND SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES. INTERNSHIPS, UNDERGRADUATE RESEARCH, SERVICE LEARNING, COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT, AND FACULTY AND PEER MENTORING ARE AT THE HEART OF THE U-ACRE MODEL.THE PROPOSED PROJECT BUILDS ON CSUF'S STRENGTHS, RESOURCES, CURRICULA, AND PRIORITIES BY PROVIDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR UNDERGRADUATES, ESPECIALLY THOSE WHO ARE HISPANIC/LATINX OR FROM UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS, TO GAIN KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE IN FANH SCIENCES AND PREPARING THEM FOR USDA MISSION-CRITICAL OCCUPATIONS.U-ACRE'S PRIMARY GOAL IS TO FACILITATE STUDENTS' ABILITIES TO IDENTIFY ISSUES SURROUNDING SUSTAINABILITY IN AGRICULTURE AND COMMUNITY FOOD SECURITY, AND APPLY SKILLS AND KNOWLEDGE OBTAINED THROUGH EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING TO DEVELOP, IMPLEMENT, AND EVALUATE WAYS TO ADDRESS THESE ISSUES. U-ACRE'S RESEARCH ACTIVITIES BENEFIT COMMUNITY PARTNERS THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF AGROECOLOGICAL METHODS REGARDING PRODUCTIVITY, WASTE DIVERSION AND COMPOSTING, AND INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT.

COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY'S (CSU) VIRTUAL VETERINARY EDUCATION TOOLS (VVET) PROGRAMMATIC MISSION HAS BEEN THE CREATION OF EDUCATIONAL TOOLS FOR USE IN UNDERGRADUATE (UG) AND VETERINARY (DVM) ANATOMY PROGRAMS AS WELL AS K-12 OUTREACH AND EXTENSION. OUR FLAGSHIP PROGRAM, VIRTUAL CANINE ANATOMY, IS AN INTERACTIVE DISSECTION PROGRAM THAT ENHANCES STUDENT LEARNING (LINTON, 2005), POTENTIALLY DECREASES EDUCATIONAL COSTS (PATRONEK, 2007), SIGNIFICANTLY DECREASES THE NUMBER OF ANIMALS NEEDED FOR ANATOMY INSTRUCTION, AND HAS MORE THAN 198,000 USERS IN 200 COUNTRIES. IN THE LAST 5 YEARS, WE EXPANDED THE SPECIES OFFERING FOR OUR VIRTUAL ANATOMY PROGRAMS, INCLUDING DEVELOPMENT OF THE OSTEOLOGY PORTION OF A VIRTUAL BOVINE ANATOMY PROGRAM. LAMENESS IN DAIRY CATTLE IS A SIGNIFICANT ISSUE AND PUBLIC EDUCATION OF FOOD ANIMAL ANATOMY AND HUSBANDRY RELATED TO WELFARE IS LIMITED (SHEARER, 2012). BY DEVELOPING ANATOMY TEACHING TOOLS THAT WE CAN USE TO ENHANCE HIGHER EDUCATION AS WELL AS ENGAGE LEARNERS FROM A VARIETY OF EDUCATIONAL SETTINGS, WE WILL DEMONSTRATE THE DIVERSITY OF IMPACT THAT CAN BE DERIVED FROM ANATOMICAL LEARNING. THE SPECIFIC AIMS THIS PROJECT ARE AS FOLLOWS: 1) THE DEVELOPMENT OF A 3D VBA PELVIC LIMB MODULE FOR DVM EDUCATION; 2) THE CREATION OF AN UG APPLIED FOOD ANIMAL ANATOMY CURRICULA; AND 3) ENGAGEMENT OF UG AND DVM STUDENTS IN LEARNING, TEACHING, AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES THAT WILL RESULT IN THE CREATION OF INDEPENDENT ANATOMICAL LEARNING MODULES FOR OUTREACH ENGAGEMENT OF PRODUCERS AND K-12 STEM LEARNERS USING VR ANIMAL ANATOMY.

FOOD PROCESSING LEADS TO MASSIVE CHANGES IN THE FOOD MATERIAL THAT ARE QUITE COMPLEX, INVOLVING CHEMISTRY, MICROBIOLOGY, AND, YES, PHYSICS. WHILE RESEARCH IN FOOD PHYSICS HAS ADVANCED SIGNIFICANTLY WITH DEVELOPMENTS IN COMPUTING AND MEASUREMENT TECHNOLOGIES, THESE ADVANCES HAVE NOT TRICKLED DOWN TO EDUCATION. WE BELIEVE THAT TRAINING IN THE ADVANCED PHYSICS OF FOOD PROCESSES WILL PROVIDE LEARNERS (IN COLLEGES AND IN INDUSTRY) WITH OPPORTUNITIES TO REDUCE RELIANCE ON TRIAL AND ERROR IN PRODUCT AND PROCESS DEVELOPMENT. INSTEAD OF BUILDING A SINGLE COURSE, WE WILL BUILD COORDINATED MULTILEVEL LEARNING MODULES THAT COMPLEMENT EACH OTHER AND ARE AVAILABLE BY THEMSELVES TO BE INCLUDED IN ANY COURSE OR AS STANDALONE. THE MODULES WILL BE FREE AND WEB-BASED FOR UNIVERSAL AVAILABILITY. THEIR MULTILEVEL APPROACH WILL MAKE THEM RELEVANT TO LEARNERS WITH A WIDE RANGE OF ACADEMIC PREPARATION, INCLUDING FOOD SCIENTISTS AND FOOD ENGINEERS. WE WILL ENSURE SUCCESS BY COLLABORATING WITH INSTRUCTORS NATIONALLY AND INTERNATIONALLY, USING THE LATEST UNDERSTANDING FROM ONLINE EDUCATION, AND CONSTANTLY ASSESSING THE STUDENT LEARNING PROCESS DURING THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE MODULES AND THEIR USE IN COURSES.

HE OBJECTIVES OF THE HEAT TRAINING ARE: (1) ENHANCE THE CAPACITY OF HIGHER EDUCATION AGRICULTURAL MECHANICS TRAINING BY USING ADVANCED TECHNOLOGIES (2) INCREASE DIVERSITY AND CULTURAL AWARENESS OF STUDENTS IN HIGHER EDUCATION, AND (3) ALIGN HIGHER EDUCATION AGRICULTURAL MECHANICS TRAINING TO INDUSTRY STANDARDS. THE CHRONIC SHORTAGE OF QUALIFIED WORKERS TO FILL VACANT POSITIONS CONTINUES TO PLAGUE MANY INDUSTRIES ACROSS THE UNITED STATES. THE AVERAGE WORKER IN THE UTILITY AND WELDING INDUSTRY HAS AN AVERAGE AGE OF 55, AND WITH THESE WORKERS NEARING RETIREMENT, THESE INDUSTRY SECTORS ARE EXPECTED TO FACE A SHORTAGE IN THE NEXT 10 YEARS. THE HEAT PROGRAM WILL PREPARE UNDERREPRESENTED, HISPANIC FAHN STUDENTS FOR THE FOR THE STEM WORKFORCE WHILE ENHANCING INTERCULTURAL AWARENESS AND DEVELOPMENT OF ALL STUDENTS INVOLVED. THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THE LOW ENGAGEMENT OF UNDERREPRESENTED STUDENTS IN THE AGRICULTURAL MECHANICS-RELATED FIELDS, AND THEIR OVERALL LOW RATES OF EDUCATIONAL ATTAINMENT--ALL OF WHICH HAVE IMPACTS TO THE 21ST CENTURY WORKFORCE NEEDS. THE COLLABORATIVE PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN ISU AND TAMUK (A HISPANIC SERVING INSTITUTION [HSI] IN SOUTH TEXAS WITH A 74.1% HISPANIC UNDERGRADUATE POPULATION) IS UNIQUELY POSITIONED TO RESPOND TO THIS NEED

THE FOOD, AGRICULTURE, NATURAL RESOURCE, AND HUMAN SCIENCES ARE EXPERIENCING COMPLEX CHALLENGES, SUCH AS CLIMATE CHANGE, POPULATION GROWTH, GLOBALIZED MARKETS AND A SHORTAGE OF QUALIFIED GRADUATES TO FILL POSITIONS, ESPECIALLY AMONG UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS. THE CURRENT EDUCATIONAL AND RECRUITMENT MODEL FOR POSTSECONDARY AGRICULTURAL EDUCATION AND CAREERS HAS FAILED TO ADEQUATELY ADDRESS THESE NEEDS.THIS PROJECT PROPOSES USING A MODEL OF HIGH-IMPACT PRACTICES (HIPS) TO ENHANCE INSTRUCTIONAL EXPERIENCES FOR STUDENTS AT UA COSSATOT, THE ONLY HISPANIC-SERVING INSTITUTION IN ARKANSAS, WHILE EXPLICITLY ENCOURAGING COSSATOT STUDENTS TO PURSUE ACADEMIC AND CAREER PATHWAYS RELATED TO PRIORITY AREAS IN AGRICULTURE. THROUGH SHARED HIPS SUCH AS, INTERNATIONAL EXPERIENCES, SERVICE LEARNING, UNDERGRADUATE RESEARCH, AND LEARNING COMMUNITIES, UA COSSATOT STUDENTS WILL HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO WORK WITH UNIVERITY OF ARKANSAS FACULTY AND STUDENTS WHILE STILL ENROLLED AT THE COMMUNITY COLLEGE. THIS SHOULD HELP UA COSSATOT STUDENTS MORE EASILY ASSIMILATE INTO THE UNIVERSITY OF ARKANSAS AND ASSUAGE CONCERNS ABOUT TRANSITIONING FROM THE COMMUNITY COLLEGE INTO A FOUR-YEAR UNIVERSITY. THE ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF STUDENTS WITH DIVERSE BACKGROUNDS MATRICULATING INTO THE U OF A AGRICULTURAL PROGRAMS, AND ENHANCE STUDENTS' LEARNING EXPERIENCES THROUGH HIGH-IMPACT PEDAGOGICAL PRACTICES TO CREATE A WELL-PREPARED, DIVERSE WORKFORCE IN THE FANH SCIENTIFIC DISCIPLINES.

PURPOSE: TEACHING AGRICULTURAL COMMUNICATIONS FOR CAREER SUCCESS (TACCS) WILL INCREASE THE NUMBER OF HISPANIC STUDENTS ACTIVELY INVOLVED IN AGRICULTURE, INCREASE CULTURAL COMPETENCY, AND WILL ASSIST IN SKILL DEVELOPMENT OF A DIVERSE GROUP OF QUALITY FANH MAJORS IN HIGHER EDUCATION.AUDIENCE: THE AUDIENCE FOR THIS PROJECT IS UNDERGRADUATE FANH STUDENTS AT TWO PUBLIC UNIVERSITIES IN ARKANSAS (UA) AND TEXAS (TAMU-K). THIS AUDIENCE WILL BE REACHED BY CREATING AND ADMINISTERING 7 REUSABLE ASYNCHRONOUS AGRICULTURAL COMMUNICATIONS CURRICULUM MODULES.PRODUCTS: THIS PROJECT WILL CREATE 7 ASYNCHRONOUS AGRICULTURAL COMMUNICATIONS MODULES TO PREPARE STUDENTS FOR FANH CAREERS BY REINFORCING THE SEVEN SOFT SKILL CLUSTERS (COMMUNICATION, DECISION MAKING/PROBLEM SOLVING, SELF-MANAGEMENT, TEAMWORK, PROFESSIONALISM, EXPERIENCES, AND LEADERSHIP SKILLS). A TOTAL OF 40 STUDENT PARTICIPANTS WILL REFLECT ON INTERCULTURAL COMPETENCY THROUGH INTERCULTURAL DEVELOPMENT INVENTORY (IDI) ACTIVITIES AND THE ADMINISTRATION OF THE INTERCULTURAL CONFLICT STYLE INVENTORY (ICS). ONE AGRICULTURAL COMMUNICATIONS GRADUATE STUDENT WILL BE HIRED TO ASSIST WITH MODULE DEVELOPMENT, DATA COLLECTION, AND RESEARCH DISSEMINATION. FIVE FACULTY MEMBERS AND 12 INDUSTRY PARTNERS (FROM FORTUNE 500 COMPANIES SUCH AS TYSON FOODS, WAL-MART, AND J.B. HUNT) WILL PROVIDE FEEDBACK TO STUDENTS THROUGH THE TEAM AND CAPSTONE PROJECTS. UPON COMPLETION OF THE GRANT, MODULES WILL BE UPLOADED TO UA WEBSITE FOR DISSEMINATION TO OTHER INSTITUTIONS.OUTCOME/IMPACT: TACCS PROJECT OUTCOMES INCLUDE THE DEVELOPMENT OF 7 AGRICULTURAL COMMUNICATION CURRICULUM MODULES, FACULTY INCREASED KNOWLEDGE OF IDI/ICS ASSESSMENTS, AND INCREASED KNOWLEDGE OF ONLINE COURSE DEVELOPMENT. ADDITIONAL OUTCOMES INCLUDE PARTICIPANTS' INCREASED KNOWLEDGE OF AGRICULTURAL COMMUNICATIONS, CULTURAL COMPETENCY AND CONFLICT RESOLUTION, AND CAREERS IN FANH.?

AREAS: "PROCESSING, DISTRIBUTION, SAFETY, MARKETING, AND UTILIZATION OF FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS"WRITTEN SUMMARY: THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES THE CHALLENGE OF EFFECTIVELY TEACHING COMPLEX CONCEPTS AND ANALYTICAL TOOLS RELATED TO FOOD PROCESSING SYSTEMS. THE INTRICATE AND OFTEN INACCESSIBLE HARDWARE USED FOR DEMONSTRATING AND TEACHING FOOD PROCESSING PRINCIPLES HAVE PERPETUALLY CHALLENGED INSTRUCTION USING CONVENTIONAL APPROACHES, PARTICULARLY FOR COMPLEX TOPICS INVOLVING FLUID MECHANICS AND MASS AND ENERGY TRANSFER PROCESSES. THE ANTICIPATED AUDIENCE FOR THE PROJECT IS UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS IN FOOD SCIENCE MAJORS THAT ARE CONSIDERING CAREERS IN THE FOOD PROCESSING INDUSTRY AFTER GRADUATION OR A POSTGRADUATE DEGREE IN RELATED FIELDS. THE TARGET OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT ARE TO DEVELOP AND EVALUATE NEW INSTRUCTIONAL APPROACHES BASED ON VIRTUAL INTERACTIVE FOOD PROCESSING ENVIRONMENTS, WHICH ARE VIEWABLE ONLINE USING CONVENTIONAL PERSONAL COMPUTERS OR VIRTUAL REALITY (VR) HEADSETS ANDCAN SUBSTITUTE FOR REAL-LIFE EQUIPMENT FOR INSTITUTIONS WITHOUT EQUIPMENT ACCESS OR PILOT PLANT INFRASTRUCTURE. ADDITIONALLY, THE PROJECT AIMS TO UTILIZE STUDENT FEEDBACK TO REFINE THESE LEARNING TOOLS AND CREATE A STRONG UNDERGRADUATE PARTICIPATORY COMPONENT. THE ANTICIPATED IMPACTS OF THE PROJECT ARE IMPROVED STUDENT UNDERSTANDING OF THE SCALE, ORIENTATION, INTERCONNECTEDNESS, AND MODELING OF FOOD PROCESSING UNIT OPERATIONS. MOREOVER, STUDENT INTEREST IN POSTGRADUATE DEGREES AND CAREERS IN FOOD SCIENCE AND FOOD PROCESSING ARE EXPECTED TO INCREASE DUE THE ENHANCED ACCESSIBILITY TO, ENGAGEMENT IN, AND COMPREHENSION OF FOOD PROCESSING CONCEPTS DURING THE PROJECT.
USING VIRTUAL REALITY TO INCREASE STUDENT UNDERSTANDING AND INTEREST IN FARM ANIMAL WELFARE

EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTIONS HAVE BEEN UNABLE TO CAPITALIZE ON AGRICULTURAL INFORMATICS-RELATED OPPORTUNITIES, DESIRED IN THE MARKETPLACE. AN AGRICULTURAL INFORMATICS CURRICULUM IS PROPOSED TO BE DEVELOPED IN COLLABORATION WITH 1862 AND 1890 INSTITUTIONS. A TOTAL OF 13 FACULTY/STAFF FROM THREE PARTNERING UNIVERSITIES WILL COME TOGETHER TO BUILD TRAINING RESOURCES TO HELP STUDENTS IN AGRISCIENCE DEPARTMENTS IMPROVE THEIR ABILITY TO 1) WRANGLE DISPARATE DATA INTO COHERENT LAYERS, FOR IMPROVED ANALYTICS AND RESEARCH CAPACITY, 2) GENERATE MODELS AND ANALYTIC METHODS TO FACILITATE REAL-TIME DECISION MAKING IN AGRICULTURE, AND 3) PRODUCE DATA ARCHITECTURES AND CODE THAT ENABLE IMPROVED DATA FLOW AND INTEROPERABILITY.OVER 1300 UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS (MORE THAN 80% UNDERGRADUATES) WILL BE IMPACTED OVER 3 YEARS GRANT PERIOD BY PARTICIPATING IN TWO-WEEK COURSE MODULE, ENROLLING IN THREE NEW COURSES, AND UNDERGOING EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING BY PARTICIPATION IN DATATHONS/HACKATHONS, ONLINE DATA SYMPOSIUM, AND INTERNSHIPS.THE COURSES WILL USE PROBLEM-BASED LEARNING AND INVERTED CLASSROOM FOR ACTIVE STUDENT PARTICIPATION. COMMUNICATION, TEAM BUILDING, LEADERSHIP, AND INDEPENDENT LEARNING WILL BE EMPHASIZED THROUGHOUT. THE EDUCATIONAL CONTENT WILL ALSO BE MADE AVAILABLE TO OTHER LAND-GRANT UNIVERSITIES AND INDUSTRY FOR WIDER USE.

THE NATION NEEDS MORE TRAINED FORESTERS, AND IT NEEDS A FORESTRY WORKFORCE THAT IS MORE REPRESENTATIVE OF THE DIVERSITY OF THE POPULATION IT SERVES. TO ADDRESS THIS CRITICAL NEED, WE ARE DEVELOPING A COLLABORATIVE PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE DEPARTMENT OF FORESTRY (DOF) AT MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY (MSU), MSU INSTITUTE OF AGRICULTURAL TECHNOLOGY (IAT), BAY COLLEGE (BC) AND MUSKEGON COMMUNITY COLLEGE (MCC), CENTERED AROUND THE DEVELOPMENT OF CURRICULUM FOR TWO NEW CERTIFICATE PROGRAMS THROUGH IAT: (1) PROFESSIONAL FORESTRY CERTIFICATE (PF) AT BC AND (2) URBAN AND COMMUNITY FORESTRY CERTIFICATE (UCF) AT MCC. THIS COLLABORATION CREATES A PATHWAY FOR STUDENTS TO COMPLETE A SPECIALIZED MSU CERTIFICATE THROUGH IAT AND AN ASSOCIATE DEGREE FROM PARTNER COMMUNITY COLLEGES IN JUST TWO YEARS. UPON COMPLETION OF THE TWO-YEAR PROGRAM, GRADUATES CAN ENTER THE WORKFORCE WITH NETWORKS CREATED THROUGH THE PROGRAM OR SEAMLESSLY MATRICULATE INTO DOF'S BACHELOR'S DEGREE PROGRAM.THIS PROGRAM WILL PROVIDE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT, EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING, AND LEADERSHIP TRAINING AND ESTABLISH ACTIVITIES DESIGNED TO PROMOTE STUDENT ENTRY, RETENTION, AND SUCCESS IN THE NEW CERTIFICATE PROGRAMS. THIS PROJECT FOCUSES ON THE HEC NEED AREAS OF CURRICULUM DEVELOPMENT, INSTRUCTIONAL DELIVERY SYSTEMS AND EXPANDING STUDENT CAREER OPPORTUNITIES AND FACILITATING INTERACTION WITH OTHER ACADEMIC INSTITUTIONS. ADDITIONALLY, THIS PROJECT ADVANCES BOTH HEC PROGRAM GOALS OF: (1) ENHANCING THE QUALITY OF INSTRUCTION FOR BACCALAUREATE DEGREES, AND (2) INCREASING THE NUMBER AND DIVERSITY OF STUDENTS COMPLETING POSTSECONDARY DEGREES.

REGISTERED DIETITIAN NUTRITIONISTS (RDNS) AND NUTRITION AND DIETETIC TECHNICIANS REGISTERED (NDTRS) PLAY AN ESSENTIAL ROLE IN FACILITATING THE HEALTH AND WELL-BEING OF INDIVIDUALS, GROUPS, AND POPULATIONS. JOB GROWTH IS ANTICIPATED FOR BOTH PROFESSIONS AS THE IMPORTANCE OF FOOD AND NUTRITION IN PREVENTING AND TREATING DISEASES AND REDUCING HEALTH DISPARITIES IS WELL-ESTABLISHED. HOWEVER, ENTRY-LEVEL DEGREE REQUIREMENT CHANGES FROM THE ACCREDITATION COUNCIL FOR THE EDUCATION IN NUTRITION AND DIETETICS (ACEND) REQUIRING THAT FUTURE RDNS OBTAIN A MASTER'S DEGREE TO SIT FOR THE NATIONAL CREDENTIALING EXAM IS PUTTING PRESSURE ON COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES TO RE-EVALUATE THEIR NUTRITION AND DIETETICS PROGRAMMATIC OFFERINGS, AS MOST DIETETIC-TRAINING PROGRAMS OPERATE AT THE BACCALAUREATE LEVEL. FURTHERMORE, RESOURCES FOR MANY COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES, BOTH PUBLIC AND PRIVATE, HAVE DIMINISHED OVER THE PAST DECADE, AND THUS INNOVATIVE APPROACHES ARE NEEDED TO DELIVER HIGH-QUALITY NUTRITION AND DIETETICS EDUCATION WHILE MEETING NEW ACCREDITATION REQUIREMENTS.IN RESPONSE TO THE NEW ACCREDITATION CHANGES, THREE INSTITUTIONS IN MILWAUKEE COUNTY, WISCONSIN, SEE THIS AS A PRIME OPPORTUNITY TO (1) REASSESS THE WAY WE DELIVER NUTRITION AND DIETETICS EDUCATION, (2) COLLABORATIVELY LEVERAGE INSTITUTIONAL RESOURCES TO FULFILL NEW REQUIREMENTS, AND (3) PROVIDE EXPERIENTIAL-LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES FOR STUDENTS TO HELP RESPOND TO SALIENT FOOD AND NUTRITION-RELATED ISSUES IN MILWAUKEE COUNTY. THESE INSTITUTIONS, THE UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN-MILWAUKEE (UWM), MILWAUKEE AREA TECHNICAL COLLEGE (MATC), AND MOUNT MARY UNIVERSITY (MMU), EACH PROVIDE NUTRITION AND DIETETIC PROGRAMS, BUT THE NEW ACEND REQUIREMENTS HAS OPENED THE DOOR FOR OUR INSTITUTIONS TO RETHINK THE WAY WE SERVE OUR STUDENTS AND OUR COMMUNITY, AS WELL AS STRENGTHEN THE EDUCATION IN THE FANH SCIENCES. FURTHERMORE, AS EACH OF OUR INSTITUTIONS ENROLL MORE STUDENTS FROM UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS, WE ARE UNIQUELY POSITIONED AND PREPARED TO HELP AMELIORATE THE SIGNIFICANT LACK OF DIVERSITY WITHIN THE DIETETIC PROFESSION. THE SOCIODEMOGRAPHIC CHARACTERISTICS OF INDIVIDUALS WHO PURSUE ACADEMIC PROGRAMS AND CAREERS IN NUTRITION AND DIETETICS IS NOT REPRESENTATIVE OF THE U.S. POPULATION, AND THE MISMATCH IS WORSE IN WISCONSIN. PROVIDING ACCESSIBLE EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES TO TRAIN A DIVERSE, COMPETENT WORKFORCE IS CRITICALLY IMPORTANT IN RACIALLY AND CULTURALLY DIVERSE, DENSELY POPULATED URBAN AREAS SUCH AS MILWAUKEE COUNTY, WISCONSIN, WHICH IS DISPROPORTIONALLY AFFECTED BY ECONOMIC INEQUALITY AND HEALTH DISPARITIES LINKED TO DIETARY INTAKE AND EATING BEHAVIOR.TO ADDRESS THESE SIGNIFICANT ISSUES, UWM, MATC, AND MMUCOLLABORATIVELY PROPOSE TO CREATE AN INTER-INSTITUTIONAL NETWORK OF GUIDED EDUCATIONAL PATHWAYS TO ENCOURAGE EFFICIENT STUDENT PROGRESSION UP THE DEGREE FOOD-CHAIN, MAXIMIZING THEIR CREDENTIALING OPPORTUNITIES AT MULTIPLE LEVELS, AND INTEGRATING EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES DRIVEN BY REGIONALLY RELEVANT CONCERNS, SPECIFICALLY FOOD INSECURITY AND HUNGER. AS MOST GRADUATES FROM OUR INSTITUTIONS FIND EMPLOYMENT IN THE GREATER MILWAUKEE AREA, THIS INITIATIVE WILL EMPOWER OUR STUDENTS WITH THE ACADEMIC CREDENTIALS AND INTELLECTUAL CAPITAL TO MAKE A PROFOUND IMPACT IN THEIR COMMUNITIES AND THE REGION.

HOW TO PROVIDE ACCESSIBLE AND CUSTOMIZED FOOD SAFETY TRAINING FOR STUDENTS OF DIFFERENT INTERESTS AND SPECIALTIES HAS BECOME A SIGNIFICANT CHALLENGE FOR HIGHER EDUCATION. ACCORDINGLY, THIS PLANNED ACTIVITY GRANT IS PROPOSED TO ADDRESS THIS CHALLENGE BY BRINGING IN INSIGHTS FROM STUDENTS, FACULTY, AND INDUSTRY LEADERS. GUIDED BY A DESIGN-THINKING MODEL, THIS PLANNING ACTIVITY GRANT AIMS TO IMPROVE FOOD SAFETY EDUCATION IN COLLEGE-LEVEL HOSPITALITY MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS IN THE U.S. THROUGH HOSTING STRATEGIC PLANNING SESSIONS AND FOCUS GROUP INTERVIEWS AMONG FACULTY, STUDENTS, AND INDUSTRY LEADERS, THIS PROJECT PLANS TO CONDUCT GAP ANALYSES AND IDENTIFY THE MAJOR AREAS THAT NEED IMPROVEMENT IN CURRENT FOOD SAFETY EDUCATION. THE FINDINGS OF THIS STUDY WILL PROVIDE VALUABLE INSIGHTS INTO HOW TO REVISE AND RE-CONSTRUCT FOOD SAFETY EDUCATION IN HOSPITALITY MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS. THE OUTPUT OF THIS STUDY WILL ALSO LEAD TO A SUBMISSION TO THE COLLABORATIVE HEC GRANT, WITH PLANS TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT ACCESSIBLE FOOD SAFETY TRAINING MODULES FOR COLLEGE STUDENTS AS WELL AS OTHER PUBLICS THAT ARE IN NEED OF SUCH INFORMATION. ADDITIONALLY, THROUGH OFFERING ACCESSIBLE AND INNOVATIVE FOOD SAFETY EDUCATION MODULES AND TOOLS, THIS PROJECT ALSO PROMOTES INNOVATIVE EDUCATIONAL PRACTICES IN FOOD SAFETY EDUCATION, WHICH WILL HELP MEET CURRENT AND FUTURE WORKFORCE NEEDS IN THE FANH SCIENCES.

THE UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON (UW) SCHOOL OF PUBLIC HEALTH HAS LAUNCHED A NEW BACCALAUREATE DEGREE PROGRAM IN FOOD SYSTEMS, NUTRITION, AND SUPPORTS THIS PROGRAM WITH STRONG EXPERTISE IN NUTRITION, HEALTH, AND FOOD AND NUTRITION POLICY. WASHINGTON STATE UNIVERSITY (WSU), AS A LAND GRANT UNIVERSITY, POSSESSES BROAD AGRICULTURE PRODUCTION AND FOOD SYSTEMS PRODUCTION EXPERTISE INCLUDING FOOD SCIENCE, PACKAGING, AND CONSUMER RESEARCH IN ADDITION TO AGRONOMY, HORTICULTURE, ANIMAL SCIENCE, AND AGRICULTURAL ECONOMICS. THE STRENGTHS OF THE TWO INSTITUTIONS ARE COMPLEMENTARY, AND THE OPPORTUNITY FOR GREATER HARMONIZATION IS TREMENDOUS. THIS PLANNING ACTIVITY IS A BLUEPRINT FOR JOINING AGRICULTURE WITH NUTRITION THAT WILL BETTER MEET FOOD, AGRICULTURE, NATURAL RESOURCES, AND HUMAN (FANH) SCIENCE EDUCATIONAL GOALS AND PRODUCE FUTURE LEADERS ACROSS WASHINGTON STATE. THROUGH THE PROPOSED WORK, UW AND WSU WILL COMPARE AND CONTRAST THEIR INSTRUCTIONAL CAPABILITIES, IDENTIFY OPPORTUNITIES FOR SYNERGY,AND LAY THE GROUNDWORK FOR A COLLABORATIVE PLATFORM IN FOOD SYSTEMS EDUCATION. THERE ARE MULTIPLE WAYS OF PROMOTING NUTRITION SENSITIVE AGRICULTURE AND FOOD- SYSTEMS-SENSITIVE NUTRITION, BUT NONE HAVE EXPLORED HOW TO CREATE AN EDUCATIONAL PLATFORM THAT DRAWS FROM BOTH THE LAND GRANT AND PUBLIC HEALTH FACULTY ACROSS INSTITUTIONS. ONCE ENVISIONED AND DEVELOPED, THIS MODEL MAY BE ADOPTED BY OTHER INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION WITH COMPLEMENTARY INSTRUCTIONAL CAPABILITIES IN FANH.

THIS COOPERATIVE PROPOSAL BETWEEN DEPARTMENTS OF ANIMAL SCIENCE AT SOUTH DAKOTA STATE UNIVERSITY (SDSU), NORTH DAKOTA STATE UNIVERSITY (NDSU), UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA-LINCOLN (UNL), AND UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA (UMN), AND THE ALLIED LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION INDUSTRY IS DESIGNED TO STRENGTHEN THE NEXT GENERATION OF LEADERS IN THE NATION'S SCIENTIFIC AND PROFESSIONAL WORKFORCE IN FOOD AND ANIMAL AGRICULTURE.STUDENTS GRADUATING FROM GRADUATE OR PROFESSIONAL PROGRAMS RELATED TO LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION ARE FREQUENTLY LESS PREPARED THAN NECESSARY FOR SUCCESS IN ALLIED INDUSTRY CAREERS. SPECIFICALLY, THEY OFTEN LACK WELL-HONED INTERPERSONAL COMMUNICATIONS SKILLS AND PRACTICAL EXPERIENCE IN LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION SYSTEMS. MEAT ANIMAL PRODUCTION IS OFTEN AT THE FOREFRONT OF HIGHLY CHARGED DEBATES AND PUBLIC POLICIES. CONSEQUENTLY, THE NEED FOR STRONG COMMUNICATION SKILLS IN GRADUATES OF ANIMAL SCIENCE PROGRAMS, INCLUDING M.S. AND VETERINARY STUDENTS, IS PARAMOUNT. WHILE UNDERGRADUATE PROGRAMS INCREASINGLY INCORPORATE 21ST CENTURY SKILLS DEVELOPMENT, THE SAME IS OFTEN NOT TRUE FOR GRADUATE STUDENTS, ESPECIALLY WITH REGARD TO THEIR ABILITY TO EFFECTIVELY COMMUNICATE WITH A NON-ACADEMIC AUDIENCE. YET IT IS THESE AUDIENCES THAT OFTEN ARE MOST VOCAL AND EXPRESS THE GREATEST CONCERN REGARDING FOOD PRODUCTION METHODS. INTERACTION WITH FOOD PRODUCERS, PURCHASERS, AND POLICY MAKERS REQUIRES A DIFFERENT COMMUNICATION STYLE THAN IS TYPICALLY EMPHASIZED IN GRADUATE TRAINING (I.E. COMMUNICATING SCIENCE TO SCIENTISTS). IT IS CRUCIAL TO FUTURE SUCCESS OF PRODUCTION AGRICULTURE THAT ACADEMICS, PRODUCERS, AND INDUSTRY BECOME MORE INVOLVED IN PUBLIC DISCUSSION AND INCORPORATE METHODS TO BUILD AND REAFFIRM THE PUBLIC'S TRUST, WHILE MAINTAINING AN EMPHASIS ON GOOD SCIENCE. TWO DECADES AGO IT WAS REPORTED MANY INCOMING ANIMAL SCIENCE STUDENTS HAD LITTLE TO NO PREVIOUS EXPOSURE TO FOOD ANIMAL PRODUCTION, AND UNFORTUNATELY THAT TREND CONTINUES TO GROW. THIS CREATES CHALLENGES COMMUNICATING WITH LIVESTOCK PRODUCERS DUE TO A LACK OF UNDERSTANDING OF THE COMPLEXITIES AND CHALLENGES OF DAY-TO-DAY LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION, YET COMMUNICATION WITH THESE INDIVIDUALS IS EXPECTED FOR MANY M.S. ANIMAL AND VETERINARY SCIENCE GRADUATES. RECENT TRENDS IN FARM LABOR SHOW AN INCREASING PROPORTION OF INTERNATIONAL WORKERS, COMPOUNDING COMMUNICATION CHALLENGES.THE SUCCESS OF AGRICULTURE-RELATED COMPANIES, LIVESTOCK PRODUCERS, AND THE FOOD INDUSTRY RESTS ON THE "SOCIAL LICENSE" TO OPERATE WHICH IS GRANTED BY OUR CONSUMERS AND SOCIETY IN GENERAL. AS PUBLIC INTEREST IN FOOD PRODUCTION INCREASES, FOOD PRODUCTION COMPANIES ARE INCREASINGLY EXPECTED TO FUNCTION WITHIN CORPORATE SOCIAL RESPONSIBILITY PRACTICES. SCIENTISTS ARE THOROUGHLY TRAINED IN CRITICAL THINKING SKILLS, RESEARCH METHODOLOGIES, AND COMMUNICATION WITH OTHER SCIENTISTS, BUT LACK TRAINING TO COMMUNICATE KEY OUTCOMES OF SCIENCE TO A NON-SCIENTIFIC AUDIENCE. YET INCREASINGLY, THE RESPONSIBILITY OF COMMUNICATING SCIENCE TO THE GENERAL PUBLIC FALLS TO THE SCIENTIST. THUS, INTENTIONAL TRAINING OF SCIENTISTS TO ACQUIRE SKILLS NECESSARY TO COMMUNICATE WITH THE PUBLIC NEEDS TO BECOME A KEY COMPONENT OF FORMAL SCIENTIFIC TRAINING.TWO KEY AREAS OF CONCERN, COMMUNICATION AND REAL-WORLD EXPERIENCE, ARE THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT AS A MEANS TO BETTER PREPARE STUDENTS FOR ENTRY INTO THE FANH SCIENCES WORKPLACE. THIS FOCUS, AND THE RESULTANT SCOPE OF THE PROJECT, WAS DEVELOPED IN DIALOG WITH INDUSTRY AND FACULTY LEADERS IN THE FANH SCIENCES; ALL PARTIES EXPRESSED AGREEMENT THAT THE POTENTIAL TO ADDRESS THESE CONCERNS WAS GREAT, BUT LARGELY UNREALIZED. THERE IS CURRENTLY NO UNIFYING INITIATIVE THAT BRINGS TOGETHER ALLIED INDUSTRIES, STUDENTS, AND TRAINING INSTITUTIONS WITH AN INTENTIONAL FOCUS ON TRAINING EXPERIENCES TO MEET THESE COMMUNICATION AND INDUSTRY EXPERIENCE DEFICITS.THE PROJECT CENTERS ON DEVELOPMENT OF A SERIES OF COMMUNICATION AND LEADERSHIP ACTIVITIES DURING A CONVENTIONAL GRADUATE PROGRAM. SUCCESSFUL DEVELOPMENT OF LEADERSHIP SKILLS IS MORE LIKELY WHEN RELEVANT LEARNING ACTIVITIES ARE INTEGRATED THROUGHOUT A COLLEGE PROGRAM RATHER THAN IN A FOCUSED, SINGLE LEARNING ACTIVITY. THIS PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO WORK IN CONCERT WITH TRADITIONAL SCIENCE AND CLASSROOM ACTIVITIES REQUIRED TO COMPLETE RESEARCH- OR COURSE-BASED M.S. DEGREES. THE SERIES OF ACTIVITIES ARE FORMULATED TO INTEGRATE PRIOR LEARNING INTO EACH SUBSEQUENT ACTIVITY TO REINFORCE EARLIER CONCEPTS.THE PROJECT'S OBJECTIVES ARE:TO DEVELOP A SERIES OF INTER-DISCIPLINARY EVENTS AROUND THE USDA EDUCATION NEED AREAS OF: CURRICULUM DEVELOPMENT, INSTRUCTIONAL DELIVERY SYSTEMS, AND EXPANDING STUDENT CAREER OPPORTUNITIES.TO PROVIDE FOUNDATIONAL GRADUATE STUDENT DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES FOCUSED IN THE AREA OF INTERPERSONAL COMMUNICATION, LEADERSHIP, AND REAL-WORLD EXPERIENCE RELEVANT TO THE FANH SCIENCES WORKPLACE.TO DEVELOP INTERDISCIPLINARY COMMUNICATION AND LEADERSHIP EXPERIENCES FOR TEAMS OF AGRICULTURE AND NON-AGRICULTURE-FOCUSED STUDENTS AROUND KEY COMMUNICATION CHALLENGE AREAS IN THE FANH SCIENCES WORKPLACE.TO DEVELOP A CADRE OF STUDENTS WHO, IN COMBINATION WITH ALLIED LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION INDUSTRY, WILL ACQUIRE KEY ANALYTICAL AND PROBLEM-SOLVING SKILLS BASED ON REAL-WORLD PROBLEMS IN THE FANH SCIENCES TO CREATE PRACTICAL SOLUTIONS.OBJECTIVES WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH:DEVELOPMENT OF A VIDEO SEMINAR SERIES DESIGNED TO TRAIN STUDENTS IN DIVERSE COMMUNICATION TECHNIQUES THAT ARE FOCUSED ON A RANGE OF COMMUNICATION FORMATS SUITABLE FOR A DIVERSITY OF TARGET AUDIENCES.AN ANNUAL COMMUNICATION CONFERENCE, IN COLLABORATION WITH ALLIED INDUSTRY, WHERE STUDENTS PARTICIPATE IN DISCUSSIONS AROUND THE NATIONAL LIVESTOCK INDUSTRY, DEVELOP SOLUTIONS FOR CASE STUDIES BASED ON REAL-WORLD SCENARIOS, AS WELL AS PRESENT EXTENSION TALKS AND SALES PITCHES FOR REVIEW BY RELEVANT EXTENSION SPECIALIST AND INDUSTRY SALES LEADERS, RESPECTIVELY.SELF-AWARENESS TRAINING PROGRAMTWO WEEK INDUSTRY INTERNSHIPSTHINK/PAIR/SHARE EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITY WHERE ANIMALSCIENCE STUDENTS PREPARE CONCISE EDUCATIONAL MATERIAL ON HOT BUTTON TOPIC RELEVANT TO FOOD ANIMAL PRODUCTION. EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS ARE EVALUATED BY STUDENTS IN HUMAN NUTRITION AND COMMUNICATION STUDY AREAS.COURSES CENTERED ON COMMUNICATING WITHIN DIVERSE CULTURESTEACHING CERTIFICATE FOCUSED ON DEVELOPMENT OF COMMUNICATION SKILLS WITHIN THE CLASSROOMTHROUGH THIS PROGRAM, "STRENGTHENING THE SCIENTIFIC AND PROFESSIONAL WORKFORCE, " MASTER'S AND VETERINARY SCIENCE STUDENTS WILL BE BETTER EQUIPPED TO HANDLE WORKPLACE DEMANDS IN THE FANH SCIENCES AND WILL HAVE ENHANCED SKILLS FOR IMPROVED COMMUNICATION WITH THE NON-AGRICULTURE COMMUNITY. THIS PROJECT INCORPORATES LEARNING ACTIVITIES USING DIRECT INTERACTION WITH FANH SCIENCE WORKFORCE LEADERS THROUGH PROBLEM-SOLVING, EDUCATIONAL AND EXTENSION ACTIVITIES, AND INTERNSHIP EXPERIENCES TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF HIGH QUALITY GRADUATES PREPARED TO LEAD THE FANH SCIENCES WORKPLACE INTO THE FUTURE.

INNOVATIONS IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF APPLIED 3D, OR VIRTUAL, TECHNOLOGIES ARE IMPACTING INDUSTRIES IN ALL SECTORS OF THE U.S. ECONOMY, AS ORGANIZATIONS INCREASINGLY SEE THE VALUE OF THESE TECHNOLOGIES FOR IMPROVED EFFICIENCY, COST SAVINGS, AND ENHANCED OPERATIONS. GRADUATES OF FOOD, AGRICULTURAL, NATURAL RESOURCES, AND HUMAN (FANH) SCIENCE PROGRAMS ARE EXPECTED TO BE SKILLED IN WORKPLACE-RELEVANT (APPLIED) VIRTUAL TECHNOLOGIES AND TO BE CAPABLE OF ADOPTING NEW ONES. THUS, THROUGH EXISTING PARTNERSHIPS WITH INDUSTRY COLLABORATORS, THE TWO-FOLD INSTRUCTIONAL OBJECTIVE IS (1) TO FOSTER AN AWARENESS OF THE IMPORTANCE OF APPLIED VIRTUAL TECHNOLOGY COMPETENCIES AMONG DIVERSE POPULATIONS OF UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS, AND (2) TO HELP THEM CULTIVATE THE APPLIED VIRTUAL TECHNOLOGY COMPETENCIES NECESSARY FOR PROFESSIONAL SUCCESS. THE TWO AUDIENCES ADDRESSED BY THIS PROJECT ARE FANH SCIENCES UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS AND ORGANIZATIONS THAT HIRE GRADUATES OF FANH SCIENCE PROGRAMS. EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS WILL BE CREATED COMPRISED OF REAL-WORLD, INDUSTRY-BASED PROBLEMS TARGETING VIRTUAL TECHNOLOGY APPLICATIONS. INSTRUCTIONAL DELIVERY STRATEGIES WILL BE CREATED TO ADDRESS STUDENTS AS DIVERSE LEARNERS. MATERIALS AND STRATEGIES WILL BE COMBINED TO FORM FIVE VIRTUAL MODULES (V-MODULES) TARGETING CORE VIRTUAL TECHNOLOGY COMPENTENCIES: CRITICAL DECISION-MAKING, COLLABORATION AND TEAMWORK, PROJECT LEADERSHIP AND MANAGEMENT, CREATIVE PROBLEM-SOLVING, AND SPATIAL VISUALIZATION. EFFECTIVENESS OF PROJECT OUTCOMES WILL BE MEASURED WITH AN ASSESSMENT TOOL CREATED TO EVALUATE THE MATERIALS AND DELIVERY STRATEGIES. WITH THE GOAL OF ENHANCING PROGRAM QUALITY AND ATTRACTING AND RETAINING A DIVERSE STUDENT POPULATION, PROJECT OUTCOMES WILL HELP TO MEET U.S. WORKFORCE NEEDS BY CULTIVATING COMPETENCIES IN APPLIED VIRTUAL TECHNOLOGIES AMONG UNDERGRADUATES AS FUTURE FANH SCIENCE PROFESSIONALS AND INDUSTRY LEADERS.

THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A SET OF COURSES AND CO-CURRICULAR LEARNING EXPERIENCES DESIGNED TO ENGAGE STUDENTS IN PROJECT-BASED COMMUNITY SERVICE CONTRIBUTING TOWARDS LASTING DISASTER RELIEF AND RESILIENCY IN PUERTO RICO AFTER HURRICANE MARIA. WE ARE WELL PREPARED TO ENGAGE IN THIS EFFORT AS OUR STUDENT-LED PROJECTS HAVE ALREADYBEEN INITIATED AS A RESULT OF A PREVIOUSLY EXISTING COLLABORATIVE EFFORT BETWEEN THESE THREE INSTITUTIONS. THE LONG-TERM GOAL OF THIS EFFORT IS TO ESTABLISH A MODEL FOR A SUSTAINABLE PIPELINE OF EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIESSTEMMINGFROM HIGHLY MOTIVATING GRAND CHALLENGES SUCH AS THESE. THE PRIMARY OPERATIONAL CHALLENGE WE OBSERVE WHEN ENGAGING STUDENTS IN THIS CONTEXT IS THAT THEIR LEARNING LIFECYCLES ARE SHORT RELATIVE TO RESILIENT PROBLEM SOLVING AFTER DISASTERS, WHICH HAS ESPECIALLY LONG PROBLEM SOLVING LIFECYCLES. THUS, TO FACILITATE SUCH EXPERIENCES, WHILE MAINTAINING STEADILY DEVELOPING AND DEMONSTRABLE OUTCOMES FOR OUR COLLABORATING COMMUNITIES, OUR OVERARCHING OBJECTIVE IS TO SOLIDIFY AND STRENGTHEN OUR COLLABORATIONS WITH CURRENT AND FUTURE LOCAL PARTNERS. THE OUTCOME WILL BE A NEW CADRE OF STUDENTS WHO ARE VERSED IN LEADERSHIP, PROJECT MANAGEMENT, AND CAPABLE OF CROSS-CULTURAL AND TRANSDISCIPLINARY GLOBAL ENGAGEMENTS WHEN PROBLEM SOLVING.

PLANT BREEDING IS A KEY COMPONENT FOR MEETING FUTURE FOOD NEEDS IN A WORLD UNDERGOING POPULATION GROWTH, A CHANGING CLIMATE, AND A SHRINKING LAND AND WATER RESOURCE BASE. AN ESSENTIAL INGREDIENT FOR BREEDING PROGRESS IS THE GENETIC DIVERSITY CONSERVED IN THE USDA-ARS NATIONAL PLANT GERMPLASM SYSTEM AND SIMILAR ORGANIZATIONS. MAINTAINING AND UTILIZING THE PLANT GENETIC RESOURCES (PGR) IN THESE GENEBANKS REQUIRE A SPECIALIZED SET OF SKILLS, BUT THERE IS A LACK OF HIGH-QUALITY MATERIALS FOR LEARNING THESE SKILLS. THIS PROJECT REPRESENTS A UNIQUE COLLABORATION BETWEEN SCIENTISTS AT COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY, IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY, AND USDA-ARS TO ADDRESS THIS NEED. THE LONG-TERM GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO EXPAND THE AGRICULTURAL WORKFORCE THAT IS WELL TRAINED IN SUBJECTS RELEVANT TO PGR ACQUISITION, PRESERVATION, DISTRIBUTION, EVALUATION, AND UTILIZATION. WE WILL DEVELOP AN ORGANIZED SERIES OF LEARNING RESOURCES (VIDEOS, EBOOK CHAPTERS, IMAGES, ETC.) COVERING PGR TOPICS; ESTABLISH AN ONLINE REPOSITORY TO HOST, ORGANIZE, AND TRACK USAGE OF THE CONTENT; DEVELOP AND OFFER THREE 1-CREDIT GRADUATE-LEVEL COURSE MODULES AT COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY ON PGR CONSERVATION AND USE IN PLANT BREEDING AND GENETICS; AND DISSEMINATE THE DEVELOPED MATERIALS BROADLY TO COMMUNITIES OF INTEREST, BOTH IN THE U.S. AND GLOBALLY. TWO GRADUATE STUDENTS WILL HELP CREATE AND EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE LEARNING RESOURCES. WE ENVISION THAT THE MATERIALS DEVELOPED IN THIS PROJECT WILL BE WIDELY INCORPORATED INTO GRADUATE AND UNDERGRADUATE AGRICULTURAL AND BIOSCIENCE COURSES, THUS ENHANCING THE UNDERSTANDING OF CROP GENETIC DIVERSITY AND ITS IMPORTANCE IN GLOBAL FOOD SECURITY. THE LEARNING RESOURCES WILL ALSO BE USED BY USDA-ARS, PRIVATE COMPANIES, AND NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS TO IMPROVE THE ABILITIES OF THEIR EMPLOYEES TO CONSERVE AND USE PGR.

WOMEN AND PERSONS OF COLOR ARE UNDERREPRESENTED IN LEADERSHIP POSITIONS IN AGRICULTURE THROUGHOUT THE US. THIS LACK OF DIVERSITY MEANS THAT THE FULL POTENTIAL OF OUR NATION IS NOT BEING UTILIZED TO FILL LEADERSHIP ROLES IN FOOD PRODUCTION AND FOOD SECURITY. TO ADDRESS THIS LACK OF DIVERSITY IN AGRICULTURAL LEADERSHIP POSITIONS, OUR PROJECT AIMS TO PROVIDE TRAINING AND EXPERIENCES TO DEVELOP SCIENCE-ENGAGED, CULTURALLY COMPETENT, RESEARCH-SAVVY WOMEN LEADERS IN ANIMAL SCIENCE. WE WILL ACCOMPLISH THIS BY PARTNERING IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY AND NORTH CAROLINA A & T UNIVERSITY TO PROVIDE INTENSE TRAINING TO A CORE GROUP OF FELLOWS IN PROFESSIONAL SKILLS, CULTURAL COMPETENCY, AND AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES, THROUGH COLLABORATIVE EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING MENTORED BY FOUR FACULTY MEMBERS. THE FELLOWS AND FACULTY MENTORS WILL EXTEND BROADER IMPACTS OF THE PROJECT THROUGH WRITTEN AND ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE BACCALAUREATE FELLOWS WITH NOVEL EXPERIENTIAL AND LEADERSHIP TRAINING TO ENHANCE THEIR CAREER SUCCESS, INCREASE THE NUMBER AND DIVERSITY OF STUDENTS IN ANIMAL SCIENCES, AND FACILITATE ENGAGEMENT BETWEEN UNIVERSITIES, WITH THE OVERALL AIM TO BRING MORE WOMEN AND STUDENTS OF COLOR SUCCESSFULLY THROUGH THE PIPELINE, WELL-PREPARED TO TAKE ON LEADERSHIP POSITIONS IN AGRICULTURE.
SUPPORTING UNDERGRADUATE TEACHING AND LEARNING ABOUT SOCIO-HYDROLOGICAL CHALLENGES THROUGH DATA-DRIVEN MODELING IN THE FANH SCIENCES

VETERINARIANS ARE A CRITICAL COMPONENT OF OUR MODERN DAY SOCIETY. THEY PROTECT ANIMAL HEALTH AND WELFARE, PROMOTE PUBLIC HEALTH, AND ENHANCE THE ECONOMIES OF THE COMMUNITIES IN WHICH THEY LIVE. IT IS VITAL THAT VETERINARIANS ENTER THEIR PROFESSIONAL CAREERS WITH COMPETENCE AND CONFIDENCE. PRIOR RESEARCH SUGGESTS THAT THE TRANSITION FROM UNIVERSITY STUDY TO VETERINARY PRACTICE IS DIFFICULT DUE TO LACK OF EXPERIENCE WITH PRACTICAL/TECHNICAL SKILLS, MANAGEMENT OF PRIMARY CASES AND CLIENT COMMUNICATION. USING REAL-WORLD CASES PRESENTED BY VETERINARIANS IN PRIMARY CARE PRACTICE PROVIDES A UNIQUE OPPORTUNITY TO EXPOSE VETERINARY STUDENTS TO THE TYPES OF CASES AND CHALLENGES THAT THEY WILL FACE FOLLOWING GRADUATION.WEB-BASED VIDEOCONFERENCING (TELEMEDICINE) WILL BE USED TO CONNECT VETERINARY STUDENTS WITH VETERINARY PRACTITIONERS TO DISCUSS THESE CASES. A NETWORK OF VETERINARIANS WILL BE ESTABLISHED BY THE PROJECT TEAM TO DEVELOP A SERIES OF 16 TELEMEDICINE SESSIONS OF APPROXIMATELY 20 MINUTES EACH. THESE SESSIONS WILL BE HIGHLY INTERACTIVE AND WILL ALLOW THE STUDENTS THE OPPORTUNITY TO DEVELOP CLINICAL DECISION MAKING SKILLS WITH ACTUAL CASES. ADDITIONAL TEACHING MATERIALS WILL BE PROVIDED TO STUDENTS BY THE RESEARCH TEAM AT THE CONCLUSION OF EACH SESSION TO ADDRESS FUNDAMENTAL PRINCIPLES OF ANATOMY/PHYSIOLOGY, DIAGNOSTICS OR THERAPY HIGHLIGHTED BY THE PRESENTED CASE. AT THE COMPLETION OF ALL SESSIONS, CONFERENCES WILL BE ORGANIZED FOR THE CLINICIANS AND STUDENTS TO NETWORK AND PROVIDE FEEDBACK TO THE RESEARCH TEAM AS TO THE EFFECTIVENESS OF TELEMEDICINE AS A COMPLEMENTARY TEACHING TOOL. IN ADDITION, AN EXTERNAL EVALUATION TEAM WILL PROVIDE FEEDBACK FOR IMPROVEMENT OF THIS APPROACH TO TEACHING AND INFORMATION AS TO THE SUCCESS OF THIS PROJECT IN ACHIEVING ITS OBJECTIVES.THE ULTIMATE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ENHANCE THE COMPETENCE AND CONFIDENCE OF GRADUATE VETERINARIANS. THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO DEVELOP AND REFINE THE USE OF TELEMEDICINE IN PROFESSIONAL CURRICULA, WHICHCOULD SUBSEQUENTLY BE USED TO INCREASE THE COMPETENCE AND CONFIDENCE OF PROFESSIONAL STUDENTS IN OTHER DISCIPLINES.

THE SMART PROGRAM BRINGS TOGETHER STUDENTS FROM A WIDE RANGE OF DISCIPLINES TO ADDRESS COMPLEX PROBLEMS IN DIVERSE CONTEXTS. STUDENTS ARE RECRUITED FROM FIELDS SITUATED ACROSS THE UNIVERSITY--E.G. APPLIED ECONOMICS AND MANAGEMENT, FOOD SCIENCE, GLOBAL DEVELOPMENT, AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES, ANIMAL SCIENCES, INFORMATION SCIENCE, ENGINEERING, AND FINE ARTS, AMONG OTHERS. THE PROJECTS THEY TACKLE, THOUGH ALL WITHIN THE AGRIBUSINESS SECTOR, INVOLVE QUESTIONS OF MARKETING AND MARKET DEVELOPMENT, VALUE CHAINS, NUTRITION AND FOOD SAFETY, FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT, EXPORT REGULATIONS, AND A NUMBER OF OTHER CHALLENGES. THE MULTIDISCIPLINARY NATURE OF THE TEAMS, COMBINED WITH THE MULTIFACETED NATURE OF THE ASSIGNED PROJECTS, PROVIDES STUDENTS WITH A HOLISTIC AND IN-DEPTH UNDERSTANDING OF AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS, SUPPLY CHAINS, AND MARKETS.ADDITIONALLY, EACH TEAM ACTS UNDER THE GUIDANCE OF AN EXPERIENCED TEAM LEADER, A CORNELL FACULTY MEMBER, AND AN EXPERT FROM THE FIELD, PROVIDING STUDENTS WITH DIVERSE AND VALUABLE INSIGHTS TO UNDERSTAND ISSUES IN THE INTERNATIONAL AGRICULTURAL SECTOR. SMART IS UNIQUE AND INNOVATIVE IN THAT IT COMBINES ELEMENTS OF SERVICE AND COMMUNITY-BASED LEARNING WITH A GLOBAL RESEARCH COMPONENT AND INDUSTRY EXPERTISE. THIS MODEL PROVIDES STUDENTS WITH A DEEP AND THOROUGH UNDERSTANDING OF THE AGRICULTURAL AND AGRIBUSINESS SECTOR IN A CONTEXT DIFFERENT FROM WHAT THEY ARE ACCUSTOMED TO. IT ALSO INTRODUCES THEM TO VALUABLE RESEARCH, ANALYSIS, BUSINESS MANAGEMENT, AND LEADERSHIP SKILLS, AND INSTILLS IN THEM VALUES INCLUDING GLOBAL CITIZENSHIP, CULTURAL HUMILITY, AND MUTUAL LEARNING.

GRAND CHALLENGES AT THE INTERFACE OF HUMANS, ANIMALS AND THE ENVIRONMENT ARE MORE "WICKED" AND URGENT THAN EVER. TO MEET THESE CHALLENGES, TRADITIONAL, SINGLE-SOLUTION PROGRESS IS INSUFFICIENT. ECOSYSTEM HEALTH (ESH), GROUNDED IN COMMUNITY-FOCUSED TRANSDISCIPLINARY SCIENCE AND DIVERSE WAYS OF KNOWING, PROVIDES A CRITICAL APPROACH TO THESE PROBLEMS. A STRONG WORKFORCE EMERGING FROM DIVERSE DISCIPLINES--INCLUDING FOOD SYSTEMS, AGRICULTURE, NATURAL RESOURCES, AND HUMAN SCIENCES (FANH)--WILL BENEFIT FROM ESH TRAINING TO BE SUSTAINABILITY-SAVVY; PREPARED TO FUNCTION IN A TRANSDISCIPLINARY, TEAM-BASED ENVIRONMENT; AND EQUIPPED WITH LEADERSHIP SKILLS NECESSARY TO NAVIGATE COMPLEX SYSTEMS, BALANCE DIVERSE STAKEHOLDERS' NEEDS, AND RESPOND TO UNFORESEEN SITUATIONS. WE AIM TO DEVELOP TRANSPARENT UNDERGRADUATE "PATHWAYS" THAT INTEGRATE CURRICULAR AND CO-CURRICULAR COMPONENTS EMPHASIZING ESH AND EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING AND THAT ARE TAILORED FOR STUDENTS IN VARIOUS DISCIPLINES; THAT ARE RESPONSIVE TO EMPLOYER AND STUDENT NEEDS, INCLUDING NEEDS OF STUDENTS OF COLOR, LOWER INCOME AND FIRST GENERATION STUDENT STATUS; AND THAT ARE DEVELOPED AND IMPLEMENTED AMONG UNITS OFFERING SUSTAINABILITY EDUCATION AND LEADERSHIP DEVELOPMENT.PROJECT ACTIVITIES ARE GROUPED INTO THREE PHASES. THE FIRST FOCUSED ON ASSESSING STAKEHOLDER (EMPLOYER, STUDENT, FACULTY) NEEDS; THE SECOND ON DEVELOPING PATHWAYS TO ESH PREPAREDNESS RESPONSIVE TO IDENTIFIED NEEDS, INCLUDING DEVELOPING NEW ESH COURSES AND FACULTY CAPACITY TO TEACH THEM; AND THE THIRD TESTING THE PATHWAYS MODEL AND CURRICULAR INNOVATIONS DEVELOPED IN PHASE 2.THIS PROJECT IS RESPONSIVE TO NIFA'S GOALS TO ENHANCE THE QUALITY OF EDUCATION FOR UNDERGRADUATE FANH STUDENTS, TO INCREASE THE DIVERSITY OF FANH STUDENTS, AND TO ENHANCE THE CONTENT EXPERTISE AND PEDAGOGICAL APPROACHES OF FACULTY.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY OVER THE PAST FEW DECADES, RECOGNITION HAS INCREASED SUBSTANTIALLY FOR THE NEED TO PROVIDE VOCATIONAL SKILLS TRAINING AND SUPPORTED EMPLOYMENT SERVICES TO INDIVIDUALS WITH DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES SUCH AS AUTISM SPECTRUM DISORDER (ASD). GREEN INDUSTRY JOBS SERVE THIS PURPOSE WELL, BUT REPRESENT AN UNDERUTILIZED EMPLOYMENT SOURCE FOR THESE TYPES OF INDIVIDUALS. HORTICULTURAL THERAPY (HT) IS THE PRACTICE OF USING PLANTS AND HORTICULTURAL ACTIVITY TO ADDRESS REHABILITATION GOALS FOR INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES. IN THIS REGARD, HT HAS SPECIFIC APPLICATIONS TO VOCATIONAL REHABILITATION. HOWEVER, VOCATIONAL REHABILITATION IN HT HAS LONG BEEN UNDERDEVELOPED BY EDUCATIONAL AND PROFESSIONAL PRACTICE STANDARDS. TO ADDRESS THIS PROBLEM, THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TWO OBJECTIVES: 1) TO DEVELOP AND DELIVER A CLASSROOM COURSE TO EDUCATE HT STUDENTS IN PROVIDING GREEN INDUSTRY SKILLS TRAINING TO INDIVIDUALS WITH ASD; AND 2) TO ESTABLISH AN ACCOMPANYING EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING INTERNSHIP OPPORTUNITY FOR THIS TRAINING. IN ALIGNMENT WITH USDA NIFA HEC GOALS, THIS NEW CURRICULUM WILL ENHANCE THE CURRENT RUTGERS HT EDUCATIONAL PROGRAM WITH THE ADDITION OF THE VOCATIONAL REHABILITATION COMPONENT. THROUGH RECRUITMENT OF STUDENTS IN HUMAN SCIENCES DISCIPLINES SUCH AS PSYCHOLOGY, SOCIAL WORK, OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY, SPECIAL EDUCATION, REHABILITATION COUNSELING, AND RECREATIONAL COUNSELING, THE NEW CURRICULUM WILL ALSO HELP TO DIVERSIFY POPULATIONS WITHIN THE FANH SCIENCES. SINCE A VOCATIONAL TRAINING SITE DOES NOT EXIST CURRENTLY IN THE STATE OF NEW JERSEY, ESTABLISHING SUCH A SITE ON THE RUTGERS CAMPUS HAS THE END GOAL OF BECOMING A STATE-APPROVED VENDOR FOR GREEN INDUSTRY SKILLS TRAINING THROUGH THE NEW JERSEY DIVISION OF VOCATIONAL REHABILITATION SERVICES, THE STATE/FEDERAL AGENCY THAT FUNDS SUCH SERVICES. SUCCESS OF THIS PROGRAM WILL SERVE AS A MODEL FOR OTHER HT PROGRAMS ACROSS THE UNITED STATES, ULTIMATELY PROVIDING BETTER-QUALIFIED SUPPORT WORKERS IN THE FORM OF HT PRACTITIONERS TO IMPROVE COMMUNITY INCLUSION AND OBTAIN STABLE EMPLOYMENT FOR INDIVIDUALS WITH ASD.

ECONOMIC GROWTH AND DEVELOPMENT IN RURAL COMMUNITIES IS HIGHLY DEPENDENT ON THE HEALTH AND WELL-BEING OF THEIR RESIDENTS,INCLUDING THOSE IN THE AGRICULTURAL AND MANUFACTURING SECTORS (FRIEDMAN, 2019). HOWEVER, RECENT EVIDENCE SHOWS THAT THEBEHAVIORAL HEALTH WORKFORCE IN RURAL COMMUNITIES IS SHRINKING NATIONWIDE (ANDRILLA, PATTERSON, GARBERSON, COULTHARD, & LARSON,2018). THIS WORKFORCE IS COMPOSED NOT ONLY OF LICENSED PSYCHIATRISTS AND PSYCHOLOGISTS, BUT OF OTHERS WHO DELIVER PROGRAMSAND SERVICES DESIGNED TO PROMOTE RESILIENCE AND HEALTHY PSYCHOLOGICAL, EMOTIONAL, AND BEHAVIORAL DEVELOPMENT AMONGCHILDREN, YOUTH, AND ADULTS. THIS BROADLY INCLUDES YOUTH DEVELOPMENT PROFESSIONALS, AS PROGRAMS ARE OFTEN PROVIDED BYNONCLINICAL SPECIALISTS WHO WORK IN DIVERSE SETTINGS, SUCH AS SCHOOLS, NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, AND YOUTH DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMS(E.G., 4-H AND AFTERSCHOOL PROGRAMS). ALTHOUGH NATIONAL PUBLIC HEALTH INITIATIVES ARE WORKING TO ENLARGE THE BEHAVIORAL HEALTHWORKFORCE IN RURAL COMMUNITIES, THESE EFFORTS ARE PRIMARILY FOCUSED ON LICENSED HEALTH AND MENTAL HEALTH PROFESSIONALS (E.G., DOCTORS AND PSYCHOLOGISTS). OF EQUAL IMPORTANCE ARE THE COMMUNITY-BASED PROFESSIONALS WHO STRIVE TO IMPROVE THE OVERALLMENTAL AND BEHAVIORAL HEALTH OF CHILDREN, YOUTH, AND FAMILIES.THIS RURAL YOUTH PROFESSIONAL FELLOWS PROGRAM FOR UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS IS DESIGNED TO BUILD AND DEVELOP KEY SPECIFICCOMPETENCIES THAT HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED BY YOUTH PROFESSIONALS IN VARIOUS PROFESSIONS (RIEBSCHLEGER ET AL., 2015; ANDERSON-BUTCHER ET AL., 2017). THE PROPOSED INSTRUCTIONAL DELIVERY SYSTEM WILL BE GUIDED BY THE FOLLOWING PRINCIPLES:RURAL YOUTH ARE HETEROGENEOUS AND YOUTH PROFESSIONALS MUST BE CULTURALLY COMPETENT AND INCLUSIVE.RURAL COMMUNITIES HAVE MANY STRENGTHS, YET THEY HAVE UNIQUE CHALLENGES THAT YOUTH PROFESSIONALS MUST UNDERSTAND AND ADDRESS.RURAL YOUTH PROFESSIONALS MUST HAVE EXPERTISE IN "YOUTH DEVELOPMENT."PROFESSIONAL PREPARATION PROGRAMS SHOULD CREATE OPPORTUNITIES FOR STUDENTS TOUNDERSTAND, APPRECIATE, AND SUPPORT ALL YOUTH LIVING IN COMPLEX AND DIVERSE RURAL COMMUNITIES.THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE AN EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING COURSE OF STUDY FOR UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS TO ENHANCE THEIR PREPARATION FOR WORKING WITH GEOGRAPHICALLY DISPERSED, RACIALLY AND ECONOMICALLY DIVERSE, AND UNDERREPRESENTED YOUTH IN RURAL COMMUNITIES.

FOOD, AGRICULTURAL, NATURAL RESOURCES, AND HUMAN (FANH) SCIENCES ARE DIFFERENT THAN TRADITIONAL "BENCH SCIENCES" BECAUSE MOST DATA COLLECTION FOR CLASS LABORATORIES AND RESEARCH OCCURS AT REMOTE FIELD LOCATIONS. RECENT SURVEYS OF STUDENTS AND RESEARCHERS REVEAL A CULTURE AT FIELD SITES WHERE SEXUAL HARASSMENT AND ASSAULT ARE TOLERATED AND UNDERREPORTED, WITH STUDENTS BEING THE MOST COMMON VICTIMS. UNIVERSITIES ARE REQUIRED BY TWO FEDERAL LAWS, TITLE IX OF THE EDUCATION AMENDMENTS AND THE VIOLENCE AGAINST WOMEN REAUTHORIZATION ACT, TO PROVIDE A SAFE WORKPLACE FREE FROM SEXUAL HARASSMENT AND VIOLENCE. THIS PLANNING ACTIVITY GRANT PROJECT WILL ASSEMBLE TWO INFORMATION-GATHERING SESSIONS WITH PANELS OF EXPERTS WHO WILL IDENTIFY WAYS TO PREVENT SEXUAL HARASSMENT AND ASSAULT DURING FIELD-BASED LABORATORIES, OVERNIGHT FIELD TRIPS, AND FIELDWORK FOR RESEARCH PROJECTS. EACH SESSION WILL FOCUS ON SPECIFIC TYPES OF REMOTE FIELDWORK, WITH THE ULTIMATE OBJECTIVE OF PRODUCING POLICIES AND IMPLEMENTATION PLANS APPLICABLE TO ALL DISCIPLINES WITHIN THE FANH SCIENCES. IDENTIFYING A SUCCESSFUL SOLUTION FOR PROVIDING STUDENTS WITH A SAFE LEARNING ENVIRONMENT REQUIRES A CONVERSATION AMONG UNIVERSITIES, STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES, AND NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS THAT HOST STUDENT RESEARCHERS AND CLASS TRIPS. THEREFORE, THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES THE USDA HIGHER EDUCATION CHALLENGE GRANTS PROGRAM EDUCATIONAL NEED AREA OF FACILITATING INTERACTION WITH OTHER ACADEMIC INSTITUTIONS

INITIATING A FIBER, TEXTILES AND CLOTHING CURRICULUM ENHANCEMENT PROGRAM TO ADVANCE CIRCULAR ECONOMY COMPETENCIES IN BACCALAUREATE EDUCATION

A CRITICAL SHORTAGE OF AGRISCIENCE TEACHERS EXISTS ON THE NATIONAL LEVEL. THE PROBLEM IS EVEN MORE ACUTE IN NEW MEXICO. FURTHER, THE QUALITY OF PROGRAM IS HIGHLY VARIABLE. A TEACHER INDUCTION PROGRAM FOR SCHOOL-BASED AGRICULTURE TEACHERS CAN PROVIDE FIRST-YEAR TEACHERS THE SUPPORT SYSTEM THEY NEED TO BE SUCCESSFUL IN THEIR TEACHING POSITION AND LEAD TO RETENTION SO THEY CAN MAKE AN IMPACT ON THEIR STUDENTS AND COMMUNITIES.

THE QUEST TO MANUFACTURE FOODS WITH TARGETED HEALTH BENEFITS IS AN UNDERPINNING GOAL OF THE MODERN FOOD INDUSTRY. UNFORTUNATELY, MOST UNDERGRADUATE CURRICULA IN FOOD SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING ARE SERIOUSLY LACKING EXPOSURE OF STUDENTS TO TOPICS RELATED TO DESIGN OF FOODS FOR HEALTH. THE FUNCTIONAL ROLE OF THE HUMAN GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT IN BREAKING DOWN FOOD MATRICES TO EXTRACT NUTRITIONAL COMPOUNDS FROM THE FOOD MACRO- AND MICROSTRUCTURE IS SELDOM TAUGHT IN DETAIL. THERE ARE NO TEXTBOOKS OR OTHER TEACHING RESOURCES AVAILABLE IN THIS AREA. TO REMEDY THIS CRITICAL DEFICIENCY, THIS PROPOSAL ADDRESSES THE DEVELOPMENT OF A COURSE FOR UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS FOCUSED AT THE INTERFACE BETWEEN FOOD SCIENCE AND NUTRITION, FOR DESIGNING THE FUTURE GENERATION OF FOODS FOR HEALTH. CURRICULAR MATERIALS WILL BE DEVELOPED USING THE "FLIPPED CLASSROOM" METHOD. THESE RESOURCES WILL INCLUDE INTERNET-MEDIATED COURSE CONTENTS, SUCH AS VIDEO TUTORIALS, VIRTUAL EXPERIMENTS, GROUP QUIZZES, GROUP DISCUSSION QUESTIONS, AND PROBLEM SETS. THE NEW COURSE WILL BE TAUGHT AT UC DAVIS, AND STUDENT LEARNING WILL BE ASSESSED. TO ENHANCE PROJECT IMPACT, ALL INTERNET-MEDIATED CONTENTS DEVELOPED IN THIS PROJECT WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE AS OPEN SOURCE FOR ANY INSTRUCTOR TO USE IN THEIR OWN TEACHING, AND AS A RESOURCE FOR FOOD INDUSTRY PROFESSIONALS. THE INFORMATION IN THE PROPOSED COURSE WILL INCREASE THE TECHNICAL SKILLS OF GRADUATES IN FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES IN A CRITICAL, EMERGING AREA, TO ENSURE THAT THE US FOOD MANUFACTURING INDUSTRY REMAINS GLOBALLY COMPETITIVE WITH ITS FUTURE HIRES WHO ARE ABLE TO PROVIDE INCREASED INSIGHT IN DESIGN OF FOODS FOR HEALTH.

THERE IS WIDESPREAD ACKNOWLEDGMENT OF THE IMPORTANCE IN DEVELOPING LEADERSHIP SKILLS OF STUDENTS STUDYING AGRICULTURE (CRAWFORD ETAL., 2011; NRC, 2009). HOWEVER, FACULTY IN TECHNICAL AGRICULTURE FIELDS MAY NOT THE REQUISITE KNOWLEDGE FOR THIS TASK. THIS PROJECT WILLDEVELOP AN ONLINE ACADEMY TO TEACH FACULTY HOW TO USE CASE STUDIES CONTEXTUALIZED IN AGRICULTURAL DISASTERS TO EMBED LEADERSHIP SKILLSIN THEIR TECHNICAL AGRICULTURE COURSEWORK. 40 FACULTY FROM AGRICULTURAL DISCIPLINES ACROSS THE SOUTHERN U.S. WILL BE SELECTED THROUGH ACOMPETITIVE PROCESS TO BECOME POLA FELLOWS (PREPARING ORGANIZATIONAL LEADERS IN AGRICULTURE). POLA FELLOWS WILL PARTICIPATE IN A14-WEEK ONLINE ACADEMY TO LEARN ABOUT AGRICULTURAL DISASTERS, LEADERSHIP DEVELOPMENT, AND CASE STUDY TEACHING. UNDER LEADERSHIP FROMTHE PROJECT TEAM, POLA FELLOWS WILL BE ORGANIZED IN TO THREE GROUPS AND THEN WILL THEN TRAVEL TO AN AREA IMPACTED BY AN AGRICULTURALDISASTER TO GATHER DATA TO CREATE A CASE STUDY. DEVELOPED CASE STUDIES WILL BE REVIEWED FOR TECHNICAL ACCURACY AND THE APPROPRIATENESS OFTHE EMBEDDED LEADERSHIP COMPETENCIES. POLA FELLOWS WILL THEN USE THE CASE STUDY IN THEIR COURSES. ALL OUTPUTS FROM THIS PROJECT WILLBE POSTED IN A PUBLICALLY ACCESSIBLE LOCATION FOR CONTINUED USAGE AFTER THE PROJECT ENDS.

THE PROPOSED PROGRAM, A PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN NORTH CAROLINA STATE UNIVERSITY (NCSU) AND NCAGRICULTURE AND TECHNICAL STATE UNIVERSITY (NC A&T) WILL ADDRESS SEVERAL OF THE STRATEGIES IN THEEDUCATIONAL NEED AREA. SPECIFICALLY, WE WILL UTILIZE A SERIES OF EXTERNSHIPS PRIOR TO AND DURING THEEARLY YEARS OF THE DVM CURRICULUM TO IMPROVE THE HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE AND PROBLEM SOLVING SKILLSOF OUR STUDENTS WITH AN INTEREST IN FOOD-ANIMAL VETERINARY MEDICINE. EXTERNSHIPS WILL PROVIDEPRACTICAL TRAINING IN ANIMAL AGRICULTURE AND FOOD-ANIMAL VETERINARY MEDICINE. AT THE COMPLETION OFTHE EXTERNSHIPS, STUDENTS WILL PRESENT THEIR FINDINGS IN A FORMAL MEETING WITH FACULTY ADVISORS,PRACTITIONERS AND FARM MANAGERS. THEN, THE STUDENTS WILL PRESENT THEIR RESULTS AT PROFESSIONALMEETINGS. TO STRENGTHEN LEADERSHIP SKILLS, STUDENTS WILL COMPLETE A ONE-WEEK LEADERSHIP PROGRAM ATTHE SHELTON LEADERSHIP CENTER, NCSU. TO ADDRESS THE NEED FOR GLOBAL ENGAGEMENT, THE STUDENTSWILL BE STRONGLY ENCOURAGED TO PARTICIPATEIN A 2 - 4 WEEK EXTERNSHIP IN A FOREIGN COUNTRY. TOEVALUATE THE PROGRAM, ONE COPD WILL USE MODERN PROGRAM EVALUATION THEORY AND MEASUREMENT, ANDTHE PROJECT WILL BEGIN WITH A LOGIC MODEL. THE BASIC MODEL CONSISTS OF FOUR FACETS: RESOURCES,ACTIVITIES, OUTPUTS AND OUTCOMES. WE ANTICIPATE THE PROJECT TO GENERATE SIX PRODUCTS, TO SUPPORT ONEFACULTY STUDY LEAVE, AND TO BENEFIT OVER 100 STUDENTS. IT IS EXPECTED THAT THE PROGRAM WILL CONTINUE WITH SUPPORT FROM THE COLLEGES AND ALLIED INDUSTRIES.

INCREASING PRESENCE OF WOMEN AND UNDERREPRESENTED MINORITIES (URMS) IN STEM-BASED FOOD,AGRICULTURAL, NATURAL RESOURCES, ANDHUMAN (FANH) SCIENCES DISCIPLINES HAS BEEN A GOAL AT LAND-GRANT INSTITUTIONS WITH MANY USING AVARIETY OF STRATEGIES. A LESS-OFTEN USED APPROACH IS CREATING COLLABORATIVE CAPACITY BUILDINGPARTNERSHIPS BETWEEN 1862 AND 1890 LAND-GRANT UNIVERSITIES (LGUS) FOCUSING ON INCLUSIVE ANDINTENTIONAL MENTORING PRACTICES. THIS PROJECT WILL REACH NEARLY 4,000 FACULTY AND STUDENTS ACROSSTEN 1862 AND 1890 LGUS CREATING COLLABORATIVE PARTNERSHIPS EMPOWERING FACULTY LEADERSHIP TEAMS(FLTS) TO DEVELOP CAMPUS-BASED MENTORING PROGRAMS. PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE TO: 1) DEVELOP MULTI-INSTITUTIONAL MENTORING NETWORK FOR TRANSFORMINGORGANIZATIONAL CULTURE (M.E.N.T.O.R.) CONSORTIUM FACILITATING INTERACTIONS AMONG FLTS FROM 1862 AND1890 LGUS TO DEVELOP EFFECTIVE RECRUITMENT AND RETENTION STRATEGIES FOCUSING ON USE OF INCLUSIVE AND INTENTIONAL MENTORING PRACTICES; 2) EMPOWER FLTS TO IMPLEMENT INNOVATIVE CAMPUS-BASED INCLUSIVEAND INTENTIONAL MENTORING PROGRAMS TO CREATE A SUPPORTIVE CULTURE INCREASING RECRUITMENT ANDRETENTION OF URMS IN FANH MAJORS; AND 3) DEVELOP AN ELECTRONIC REPOSITORY OF BEST PRACTICES AND INNOVATIVE MODELS TO ENHANCE A SUPPORTIVECULTURE FOR INCLUSIVE AND INTENTIONAL MENTORING OF URMS IN FANH. THIS PROJECT ENHANCES THECOLLECTIVE CAPACITY BETWEEN TWO DISPARATE LGU TYPES, IDENTIFYING CHALLENGES AND DEVELOPING EFFECTIVE STRATEGIES TO INCREASE DIVERSITY IN STEM-BASED FANH SCIENCESDISCIPLINES.

WE ARE PROPOSING A NEW PROJECT TO ADDRESS FOUR SIGNIFICANT CHALLENGES RELATED TO FORESTRY EDUCATION: 1) TO INCREASE OVERALL NUMBERS OF TRAINED FORESTRY GRADUATES, 2) TO BROADEN PARTICIPATION OF UNDERREPRESENTED MINORITIES IN THE FORESTRY PROFESSION, 3) TO INCREASE ENGAGEMENT OF URBAN POPULATIONS IN FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, AND 4) TO EXPOSE ALL STUDENTS TO A DIVERSITY OF PEOPLE AND EXPERIENCES AS A CORE COMPONENT OF THEIR PROFESSIONAL TRAINING. TO ACCOMPLISH THESE GOALS, WE ARE FORMING A PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE DEPARTMENT OF FORESTRY (DOF) AT MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY (MSU) AND THE DEPARTMENT OF CHEMISTRY AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE (CES) AT MEDGAR EVERS COLLEGE (MEC), CENTERED AROUND THE DEVELOPMENT OF A NEW 3+2 CURRICULUM. THE NEW 3+2 PROGRAM WILL ALLOW STUDENTS TO EARN A B.S. IN ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE FROM MEC AND A M.S. IN FORESTRY FROM MSU IN JUST 5 YEARS. THE PROGRAM WILL INCLUDE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT AND LEADERSHIP TRAINING, AND WILL CONTRIBUTE TO A DIVERSE WORKFORCE WITH OUTSTANDING EXPERIENCE IN FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT. THE TARGET AUDIENCE INCLUDES: 1) UNDERREPRESENTED MINORITY (URM) UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS FROM THE NEW YORK CITY METROPOLITAN AREA, 2) CURRENT STUDENTS IN MSU'S PROFESSIONAL FORESTRY DEGREE PROGRAM, AND 3) EMPLOYERS WHO CURRENTLY HAVE GREAT DIFFICULTY RECRUITING NON-CAUCASIAN EMPLOYEES FOR PROFESSIONAL FORESTRY POSITIONS (SAMPLE ET AL. 2015).  WE EXPECT THIS PROGRAM TO RESULT IN SEVERAL IMPORTANT TRANSFORMATIONS IN FOOD, AGRICULTURAL, NATURAL RESOURCES AND HUMAN (FANH) SCIENCES EDUCATION THROUGH THE ACCOMPLISHMENT OF FOUR TARGET OBJECTIVES:1) INCREASE INTEREST IN THE FIELDS OF FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AMONG ENVIRONMENTALLY-INTERESTED URM STUDENTS FROM THE NEW YORK CITY METROPOLITAN AREA.2) BROADEN PARTICIPATION IN THE FORESTRY PROFESSION BY STUDENTS FROM DIVERSE BACKGROUNDS.3) EXPOSE TRADITIONAL STUDENTS IN OUR PROFESSIONAL FORESTRY PROGRAM TO MORE DIVERSE PERSPECTIVES AND EXPERIENCES, TO BETTER PREPARE THEM FOR THE 21ST CENTURY WORKPLACE.4) PROVIDE A TEMPLATE FOR EXPANDING THIS MODEL TO NEW INSTITUTIONS AND NEW FANH DISCIPLINES.

THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THE HEC PROGRAM GOALS OF ENHANCING INSTRUCTION AND INCREASING THE NUMBER AND DIVERSITY OF STUDENTS WHO WILL PURSUE AND COMPLETE POST-SECONDARY DEGREES IN FANH SCIENCES BY ADDRESSING THREE EDUCATIONAL NEED AREAS: 1) CURRICULUM DEVELOPMENT, INSTRUCTIONAL DELIVERY SYSTEMS AND EXPANDING STUDENT CAREER OPPORTUNITIES; 2) FACULTY PREPARATION AND ENHANCEMENT FOR TEACHING, AND 3) FACILITATING INTERACTION WITH OTHER ACADEMIC INSTITUTIONS. ACTIVITIES THAT WILL BE IMPLEMENTED INCLUDE: FACULTY DEVELOPMENT IN STEM AND PEDAGOGY THROUGH THE CURRICULUM FOR AGRICULTURAL SCIENCE EDUCATION (CASE), AP CREDIT TRANSFER BETWEEN BOLTON HS AND STCC AND/OR TSU FOR 4 COURSES/12 HOURS OF CREDIT, NEW STCC A.S. DEGREES/TENNESSEE TRANSFER PATHWAYS IN ANIMAL SCIENCE, PLANT SCIENCE, & AG BUSINESS, 2+2 AGREEMENT & CURRICULUM ALIGNMENT FOR BS COMPLETION, LECTURE-CAPTURE LAB DEVELOPMENT AND COURSE SHARING, EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING, SUMMER APPRENTICESHIP, PROGRAM INTEGRATION, AGRICENTER SUMMER EXPERIENCES, LEADERSHIP EDUCATION, MARKETING/RECRUITING, AND EVALUATION/DISSEMINATION. EXPECTED LONG-TERM IMPACTS INCLUDE: DEVELOPMENT OF A CADRE OF STUDENTS PURSUING HIGHER EDUCATION DEGREES IN FANH SCIENCES; INCREASE IN HUMAN CAPITAL TO MEET FUTURE NATIONAL FOOD, AGRICULTURE, NATURAL RESOURCE AND HUMAN (FANH) SCIENCE WORKPLACE NEEDS, INCREASED HUMAN CAPITAL TO SERVE UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES (I.E. MEMPHIS, NASHVILLE, ETC), INCREASED DIVERSITY OF FANH STUDENTS AND THOSE CHOOSING FANH SCIENCES CAREERS.

VERY FEW AGRICULTURE TEACHING CERTIFICATION DEGREE PROGRAMS INCLUDE WILDLIFE ECOLOGY AND MANAGEMENT COURSES, YET HIGH SCHOOL AGRICULTURE EDUCATORS ARE EXPECTED TO COVER THESE TOPICS IN THEIR COURSES. TO ADDRESS THIS GAP IN SKILLS, WE PROPOSE THE WILDLIFE EDUCATION AND SUSTAINABILITY TRAINING (WEST) PROGRAM, AN INTEGRATED EDUCATION AND RESEARCH PROPOSAL. THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF POST-SECONDARY STUDENTS AND EDUCATIONAL PROFESSIONALS TRAINED IN FOOD, AGRICULTURAL, NATURAL RESOURCES, AND HUMAN SCIENCES (FANH) THROUGH A 4-DAY WORKSHOP OF IMMERSIVE LEARNING EXPERIENCES, SO THEY CAN INTEGRATE FANH TOPICS IN GREATER DEPTH IN THEIR EDUCATION PROGRAMS. THE GOAL OF THIS MULTI-INSTITUTIONAL AND MULTI-DISCIPLINARY PROJECT, ENTITLED WILDLIFE EDUCATION AND SUSTAINABILITY TRAINING (WEST) PROGRAM IS TO: 1) DEVELOP A STATE AND NATIONAL STANDARDS ALIGNED CURRICULUM OF EXPERIENTIAL LESSONS FOCUSED ON WILDLIFE ECOLOGY AND MANAGEMENT FOR USE POST-SECONDARY AGRICULTURE TEACHER PREPARATION , 2) CONDUCT FREE, ANNUAL 4-DAY PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT WORKSHOPS TO PROVIDE AN EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING EXPERIENCE FOR PRE-SERVICE TEACHERS WHILE TRAINING THEM IN USE OF THE CURRICULUM, 3) PROVIDE LEADERSHIP SCHOLARSHIPS AND PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR TRAINED PRE-SERVICE TEACHERS TO PRESENT A LESSON-BASED TRAINING WORKSHOP AT A STATE TEACHER CONFERENCE, AND 4) CONDUCT RESEARCH ON THE PROGRAM'S EFFECTIVENESS. PRE-SERVICE AGRICULTURE SCIENCE AND OTHER ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATORS WILL BE ELIGIBLE TO APPLY TO THE WEST PROGRAM. THIS PROPOSAL WILL DIRECTLY IMPACT 90 POST-SECONDARY STUDENTS AND FOCUSES ON WILDLIFE ECOLOGY AND MANAGEMENT NIFA PRIORITY AREAS.

IN 2015 THE STATE OF TENNESSEE INITIATED A PROGRAM KNOWN AS TENNESSEE PROMISE WHICH PROVIDES LAST DOLLAR SCHOLARSHIPS FOR COMMUNITY COLLEGES. CURRENTLY, THERE IS NO COHESIVE STATEWIDE STRATEGY AMONG THE UNIVERSITIES AND COLLEGES TO DEVELOP A SEAMLESS TRANSFER PATHWAY THAT CONNECTS ASSOCIATE PROGRAMS WITH FOUR YEAR INSTITUTIONS. AS A RESULT, THERE IS A NEED TO DEVELOP A CLEAR PATHWAY THAT LEADS TO A BACHELOR'S DEGREE AT THE PUBLIC AND PRIVATE UNIVERSITIES ACROSS THE STATE. DEVELOPING A SEAMLESS TRANSITION FROM AN ASSOCIATE DEGREE TO A UNIVERSITY WILL HELP INCREASE THE QUALITY OF THE STATES' WORKFORCE AND IMPROVE ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT ESPECIALLY IN RURAL AREAS.THE OBJECTIVE IS TO DEVELOP A PLANNING CONFERENCE THAT WILL BRING KEY PLAYERS TOGETHER TO DEVELOP A SEAMLESS TRANSFER PATHWAY THAT CAN IMPROVE THE NUMBER AND QUALITY OF STUDENTS OBTAINING DEGREES IN THE FANH DISCIPLINE AREAS ACROSS THE STATE. THE COLLABORATION AMONG COMMUNITY AND TECHNIAL COLLEGES AND FOUR UNIVERSITIES WILL ENABLE BETTER COORDIANTION OF STATE RESOURCES IN HIGHER EDUCAITON AND WILL LEAD TO MORE ACCESS TO HIGHER EDUCATION OPPORTUNITES FOR TENNESSEE RESIDENTS.

THIS PROPOSAL IS A MULTISTATE COLLABORATION ASSOCIATED WITH AN ONGOING USDA MULTISTATE PROJECT (NC1023: ENGINEERING FOOD SAFETY AND QUALITY) ON IMPROVING TEACHING AND LEARNING OF NON-ENGINEERING STUDENTS IN FOOD PROCESSING AND FOOD ENGINEERING COURSES. THE CURRENT COMBINATION OF A LECTURE-CENTERED TEACHING STYLE, UNDERPREPARED STUDENTS, AND LACK OF STUDENT EXPERIENCE IN SMART-FOOD MANUFACTURING AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES HAS LIMITED THE PREPARATION OF NEXT-GENERATION FOOD SCIENTISTS AND ENGINEERS. TO ADDRESS THIS ISSUE, THIS PROJECT WILL APPLY AND EVALUATE EVIDENCE-BASED, STUDENT-CENTERED INNOVATIVE INSTRUCTIONAL DELIVERY MODELS IN FOOD PROCESSING AND FOOD ENGINEERING COURSES ACROSS SIX LAND-GRANT INSTITUTIONS IN THREE REGIONS OF THE UNITED STATES. THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ENHANCE STUDENT LEARNING EXPERIENCES IN FOOD PROCESSING AND ENGINEERING, IMPROVING STUDENTS' ABILITY TO SOLVE COMPLEX, REAL-WORLD PROBLEMS, AND CREATING A MORE PREPARED 21ST CENTURY U.S. WORKFORCE. KEY ELEMENTS OF THE INSTRUCTIONAL CHANGES IN THIS PROJECT INCLUDE 1) COLLECTING DATA, INCLUDING PRE-AND-POST SURVEYING, INSTITUTIONAL RETENTION DATA, AND FOCUS GROUP DISCUSSIONS INVOLVING STUDENTS AND INDUSTRY PROFESSIONALS, TO DETERMINE KEY AREAS OF EMPHASIS TO STRENGTHEN STUDENTS' PREPARATION TO ENTER THE WORKFORCE; 2) CREATING A COMMON, THEMED GROUP PROJECT FOR ALL INSTITUTIONS; 3) ENGAGING UNDERGRADUATE FELLOWS TO PROVIDE ADDITIONAL STUDENT HELP SESSIONS; AND 4) DEVELOPING FACULTY TRAINING/WORKSHOPS ON HOW TO MODIFY CONTENT DELIVERY TO ADDRESS KEY STUDENT WEAKNESSES USING ADVANCED INSTRUCTIONAL TECHNOLOGIES. THE OUTCOMES AND PRODUCTS FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE USED TO IMPROVE SIMILAR NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL PROGRAMS INCORPORATING FOOD SCIENCE, PROCESSING, AND ENGINEERING COURSES.

THIS PROJECT WILL INITIATE A SCHOOL OF URBAN AGRICULTURE AT THE UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN-MADISON IN PARTNERSHIP WITH TWO NONPROFITS, COMMUNITY GROUNDWORKS (CGW) AND THE CENTER FOR RESILIENT CITIES (CRC), BOTH NATIONALLY RECOGNIZED FOR THEIR EXPERTISE IN URBAN AGRICULTURE PROGRAM DESIGN, IMPLEMENTATION AND WORKFORCE DIVERSITY. THE PROJECT OFFERS A NEW APPROACH TO SCIENCES EDUCATION AND TRAINING IN URBAN AGRICULTURE AND RELATED SCIENCES BY SIMULTANEOUSLY CREATING CURRICULA THAT MEETS THE NEEDS OF STUDENTS SEEKING SHORT, INTENSE TRAINING IN SPECIFIC ASPECTS OF URBAN AGRICULTURE (WORKSHOP AND SHORT COURSE INSTRUCTION) AND THE NEEDS OF FOUR-YEAR BACCALAUREATE STUDENTS WHO ARE INTERESTED IN ENHANCING THEIR EDUCATION IN THIS EMERGING CONTENT AREA.THE PROJECT'S TARGET AUDIENCE INCLUDES UW UNDERGRADUATES, SECONDARY STUDENTS IN THE PIPELINE TO ENTER UW (NOW ENGAGED IN PRE-COLLEGE PROGRAMS EMPHASIZING FOOD SYSTEMS), AND NON-CREDIT STUDENTS SUCH AS FARMERS AND NON-PROFIT MANAGERS. THEY WILL GAIN TECHNICAL TRAINING, SCIENCE-BASED SKILLS AND LEADERSHIP SKILLS (E.G., NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATION MANAGEMENT, COMMUNITY RELATIONS) ASSOCIATED WITH URBAN FARMING. TO ACCOMPANY THEIR ON-CAMPUS TRAINING, STUDENTS WILL BE PLACED IN EXTERNSHIPS AT CGW'S TROY COMMUNITY FARM, CRC'S BADGER ROCK CENTER, AND OTHER GARDEN NETWORK SITES ACROSS MADISON. PROJECT OUTCOMES WILL INCLUDE: LAUNCHING A NEW SCHOOL FOR URBAN AGRICULTURE, CURRICULAR MATERIALS FOR THREE TYPES OF PROGRAMS TESTED OVER TWO YEARS OF STUDENT ENROLLMENT, A COMMUNITY ORGANIZATION AND UNIVERSITY RELATIONSHIP BRIEF (BEST PRACTICES FOR NONPROFITS PARTNERING WITH UNIVERSITIES) AND A NEW FRAMEWORK FOR AN URBAN AGRICULTURE COMMUNITY OF PRACTICE DISSEMINATED THROUGH THE ONLINE COMMUNITY FOOD SYSTEMS TOOLKIT HOSTED BY UW EXTENSION.

THE GOAL OF THIS MULTI-INSTITUTIONAL AND MULTI-DISCIPLINARY PROJECT IS TO PREPARE FUTURE AGRICULTURE, ENGINEERING, AND NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS TO ADDRESS THE COMPLEXITIES OF MANAGING FOR MULTIPLE USES AND WORKING WITH STAKEHOLDERS THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF GRADUATE STUDENT AND FACULTY EXPERIENCES IN SYSTEMS THINKING (ST) AND SYSTEMS DYNAMICS (SD). NATURAL RESOURCE ISSUES ARE FREQUENTLY DEEMED "WICKED PROBLEMS" THAT INVOLVE "HARD SYSTEMS" (ECOSYSTEM STRUCTURE AND PROCESSES) AND "SOFT SYSTEMS" (DIVERSE VALUES OF STAKEHOLDERS) THAT BOTH INFORM AND ARE INFLUENCED BY MANAGEMENT DECISIONS. THE AUDIENCE FOR THIS PROJECT INCLUDES MASTER'S AND PHD STUDENTS ENROLLED IN AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCE PROGRAMS AT THE MULTIPLE PARTICIPATING INSTITUTIONS AND THEIR FACULTY MENTORS. GRADUATE STUDENTS IN THESE PROGRAMS ARE TRAINING TO BECOME MANAGERS OF NATURAL RESOURCE SYSTEMS AND WILL LIKELY BE CHALLENGED TO ADDRESS WICKED PROBLEMS THROUGHOUT THEIR PROFESSIONAL CAREERS THAT EXIST AT THE NEXUS OF FOOD, ENERGY, AND WATER SYSTEMS.TO ADDRESS THESE NEEDS, FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES GUIDE THIS PROJECT:#1: DEVELOP A ONE-YEAR FELLOWSHIP, ENTITLED THE "FOOD, ENERGY, AND WATER SYSTEMS FELLOWSHIP," FOR GRADUATE STUDENTS AND FACULTY THAT JOINS OUR FOUR INSTITUTIONS IN TRAINING THE NEXT GENERATION OF AGRICULTURE PROFESSIONALS WHO CAN ADDRESS WICKED FOOD, ENERGY, AND WATER ISSUES.

AGRICULTURAL DRAINAGE, A PRACTICE THAT IS CRITICAL FOR FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION ON SOME OF THE MOST PRODUCTIVE LANDS OF THE U.S, IS UNDERGOING MAJOR CHANGES. DRAINAGE DESIGNS THAT PREVIOUSLY FOCUSED ONLY ON REMOVAL OF EXCESS WATER NOW NEED TO FULFILL THE ADDITIONAL GOAL OF IMPROVING WATER QUALITY TO MEET INCREASING SOCIETAL EXPECTATIONS OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION, WHILE MAINTAINING COST-EFFECTIVENESS. DESIGNING EFFECTIVE DRAINAGE SYSTEMS THAT BALANCE FARMERS' ECONOMIC OBJECTIVES WITH OTHER SOCIETAL, ENVIRONMENTAL, AND POLICY CONSIDERATIONS WILL REQUIRE MORE HOLISTIC EDUCATION THAN WAS COMMON IN THE PAST. MOREOVER, WHILE THE NEED FOR ENGINEERS WITH THESE SKILLS HAS INCREASED, THE NUMBER OF STUDENTS TAKING DRAINAGE-RELATED COURSES HAS DECREASED, AND IT IS THEREFORE DIFFICULT FOR ANY SINGLE INDIVIDUAL OR UNIVERSITY TO UNDERTAKE THE TASK OF CREATING CURRICULA THAT WILL ENABLE STUDENTS TO DEVELOP THE NEXT GENERATION OF DRAINAGE STRATEGIES TO MEET SOCIETY'S GROWING NEEDS.TOMEET THIS INSTRUCTIONAL CHALLENGE, OUR TEAM OF DRAINAGE RESEARCHERS AND EDUCATORS FROM FIVE INSTITUTIONS IN FOUR STATES (IOWA, ILLINOIS, INDIANA, OHIO) PROPOSES TO DEVELOP A CUSTOMIZABLE AGRICULTURAL DRAINAGE CURRICULUM FOR EDUCATING STUDENTS IN AGRICULTURAL OR BIOLOGICAL ENGINEERING, TECHNOLOGY, CROP SCIENCES, WATER RESOURCES MANAGEMENT, AND RELATED FIELDS. THE AUDIENCE INCLUDES THE STUDENTS WHO WILL BENEFIT FROM INCREASED LEARNING AND RESULTING EMPLOY-MENT OPPORTUNITIES, AGRICULTURAL PRODUCERS, THE DRAINAGE INDUSTRY, AND THE DOWNSTREAM PUBLIC WHO WILL BENEFIT FROM IMPROVED DRAINAGE SYSTEMS DESIGNED BY STUDENTS WHO GAIN THIS EXPERTISE.OUR OVERALL GOAL IS TO ENHANCE THE CAPACITY OF INSTITUTIONS TO OFFER DRAINAGE EDUCATION THAT INCLUDES THE TECHNICAL AND CONTEXTUAL ELEMENTS THAT ARE NECESSARY FOR SOLVING PRESENT DAY DRAINAGE CHALLENGES AND INTERESTING TO MORE DIVERSE GROUPS OF STUDENTS. OUR PROJECT WILL DEVELOP THE CURRICULUM, EVALUATE AND IMPROVE IT THROUGH A CYCLE OF PILOT TESTING AND FORMATIVE ASSESSMENT, APPLY IT AT THE FOUR UNIVERSITIES INCLUDED IN THIS PROJECT, AND THEN DISSEMINATE IT BROADLY FOR IMPROVEMENT OF WATER MANAGEMENT EDUCATION, RESULTING IN IMPROVED DRAINAGE DESIGNS FOR PRODUCTION AND WATER QUALITY.

THE FAMILY AND CONSUMER SCIENCES (FCS) PROFESSION HAS DOCUMENTED A NATIONAL NEED FOR INCREASING THE NUMBER OF FCS EDUCATORS FOR THE WORKFORCE. THE NATIONWIDE CLOSURE OF 153 FCS EDUCATOR PREPARATION PROGRAMS HAS DISADVANTAGED INDIVIDUALS WHO WANT TO JOIN THE FCS WORKFORCE AND EMPLOYERS WHO WANT TO FILL VACANT FCS EDUCATOR POSITIONS. THE NATIONAL PARTNERSHIP TO RECRUIT, PREPARE, AND SUPPORT HUMAN SCIENCES/FAMILY CONSUMER SCIENCES EDUCATORS PROJECT IS FACILITATING COLLABORATIVE INTERACTION WITH EDUCATION INSTITUTIONS, STATE DEPARTMENTS OF EDUCATION, EXTENSION, K-12 EDUCATORS AND STUDENTS, PROFESSIONAL ASSOCIATIONS, STUDENT ORGANIZATIONS, AND INDUSTRY PARTNERS ON A NATIONWIDE BASIS TO RECRUIT, PREPARE, AND SUPPORT FCS EDUCATORS. THE PROJECT USES LICENSURE INFORMATION, CURRICULUM AND WEBINAR LIBRARIES, ONLINE COURSES PROVIDED BY MULTIPLE INSTITUTIONS, TRADITIONAL AND ALTERNATIVE LICENSURE MODEL RECOMMENDATIONS, STUDENT SUPPORT INFORMATION, LEADERSHIP ACADEMY SUMMITS, MARKETING CAMPAIGNS AND PRODUCTS, AND TARGETED REGIONAL SUPPORT ACTIVITIES TO CREATE AND IMPLEMENT HOLISTIC INITIATIVES FOR RECRUITING, PREPARING, AND SUPPORTING FCS EDUCATORS. BY COMBINING RESOURCES AND SHARING EXPERTISE TO CREATE AND USE BEST PRACTICE MODELS, THE STAKEHOLDERS WILL CREATE NATIONAL RESOURCES THAT CAN BE ACCESSED AND REPLICATED OR ADAPTED AT STATE LEVELS WITH STATE STAKEHOLDERS. COMBINING UNIVERSITY RESOURCES AND GRANT FUNDS WITH PROFESSIONAL AND STUDENT ASSOCIATION RESOURCES AND WITH INDUSTRY AND EDUCATION PARTNER EXPERTISE, CREATES A SYNERGY THAT FACILITATES A COST EFFECTIVE, COLLABORATIVE, AND HOLISTIC APPROACH TO RECRUITING, PREPARING, AND SUPPORTING FCS EDUCATORS TO MEET STATE AND NATIONAL WORKFORCE NEEDS THAT CAN BE REPLICATED AND SUSTAINED OVER TIME.

TWO NEW YORK STATE COLLEGES OF AGRICULTURE WILL WORK TOGETHER TO BUILD LINKAGES AND GENERATE A CRITICAL MASS OF EXPERTISE THAT WILL 1) INCREASE THE NUMBER AND DIVERSITY OF STUDENTS PURSING AND COMPLETING UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE DEGREES IN PLANT SCIENCE; 2) IMPROVE THE OVERALL RELEVANCE, CONTENT AND QUALITY OF INSTRUCTION IN PLANT SCIENCE COURSES; AND 3) ADEQUATELY PREPARE STUDENTS TO SUCCEED IN PLANT SCIENCE GRADUATE PROGRAMS. SUNY COBLESKILL WILL UTILIZE THE PLANT SCIENCE AND TEACHER TRAINING EXPERTISE AT CORNELL TO IMPROVE ITS PLANT SCIENCE CURRICULUM AND TEACHING PEDAGOGY. COBLESKILL WILL ADAPT ITS CURRICULUM TO EVIDENCE-BASED METHODS REFLECTING HOW TODAY'S STUDENTS LEARN WHILE CREATING A NEW PLANT SCIENCE BACHELORS OF SCIENCE DEGREE THAT ALIGNS WITH CORNELL'S MASTERS OF PROFESSIONAL STUDIES PROGRAM IN PLANT SCIENCE. CORNELL WILL CREATE NEW PLANT SCIENCE COURSES IN RESPONSE TO INDUSTRY NEEDS AND WILL ALSO UPGRADE ITS TEACHING PEDAGOGY THROUGH PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT TRAINING. THE END PRODUCT WILL BE AN ARTICULATION AND COURSE ALIGNMENT ARRANGEMENT THAT CORNELL CAN REPLICATE WITH OTHER UNDERGRADUATE COLLEGES TO INCREASE THE NUMBER AND DIVERSITY OF STUDENTS PURSING GRADUATE DEGREES IN PLANT SCIENCE AND INCREASING THE PERCENTAGE WHO SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETE THE DEGREE PROGRAM.

THE CONTINUING RAPID GROWTH IN INTEREST IN FERMENTED FOODS AND BEVERAGES, SUCH AS BEER, WINE, YOGURT, AND FERMENTED VEGETABLES, HAS CREATED AN INCREASED DEMAND FOR EMPLOYEES WITH TECHNICAL TRAINING RELATED TO THEIR PRODUCTION. IN RESPONSE TO THIS DEMAND, EASTERN MICHIGAN UNIVERSITY, A REGIONAL COMPREHENSIVE UNIVERSITY WITH SIGNIFICANT MINORITY ENROLLMENT, HAS CREATED NEW MAJOR AND MINOR UNDERGRADUATE DEGREES IN FERMENTATION SCIENCE, WHICH WILL PROVIDE STUDENTS PRACTICAL, HANDS-ON TRAINING IN THE SCIENCE OF THE CHEMICAL AND BIOLOGICAL PROCESSES OF FERMENTATION. GIVEN THE INFANCY OF THE FIELD OF FERMENTATION SCIENCE, THERE IS NOT A STANDARD CURRICULUM TO BE USED AS A TEMPLATE, NOR ARE THERE NUMEROUS STANDARD EXPERIMENTS OR TEXTBOOKS AVAILABLE TO "PLUG IN" TO A NEW PROGRAM. THE GOALS OF THIS PROPOSED PROJECT ARE (1) TO CREATE AND INTEGRATE PRACTICAL EXPERIENCES INTO THE CURRICULUM IN ORDER TO PREPARE STUDENTS FOR THEIR SENIOR-YEAR INTERNSHIPS, (2) TO DEVELOP CLOSER RELATIONSHIPS WITH BUSINESSES IN THE FERMENTATION INDUSTRY TO OPTIMIZE TRAINING OF POTENTIAL TECHNICAL EMPLOYEES, AND (3) TO PROVIDE ACCESS TO THIS INDUSTRY TO HISTORICALLY UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS. THE BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE THE STUDENTS WITHIN THE PROGRAM, ESPECIALLY THOSE FROM UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS, AS THEY RECEIVE A GREATER AMOUNT OF CONTEXTUALLY RELEVANT TRAINING AND OUR EXTERNAL PARTNERS IN THE FERMENTATION COMMUNITY, WHO HOST OUR INTERNSHIPS AND HIRE OUR GRADUATES, AND WILL BENEFIT FROM A STUDENT/EMPLOYEE WITH A LARGER BASE OF PRACTICAL TRAINING. CURRICULAR MATERIALS AND PROCEDURES WILL BE DISSEMINATED AND MADE AVAILABLE TO THE EDUCATION COMMUNITY FOR USE OR ADAPTATION.

WE WILL CREATE AN UNDERGRADUATE CERTIFICATE IN URBAN AND COMMUNITY FORESTRY (U&CF) AT THE UNIVERSITY OF KENTUCKY. BROAD IN SCOPE, THIS PROGRAM WILL FILL A GAP IN STUDENT EXPOSURE TO URBAN AND COMMUNITY FORESTRY AND ADDRESS THE EXPANDING NEED FOR NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS TRAINED IN MULTIPLE ASPECTS OF URBAN FORESTS. WE ANTICIPATE THAT OVER THE 3-YEAR GRANT PERIOD 60 STUDENTS WILL BE TRAINED IN U&CF, A FIELD OF STUDY NOT CURRENTLY OFFERED IN THE REGION. STUDENTS IN THE U&CF PROGRAM WILL GAIN AN INTERDISCIPLINARY UNDERSTANDING OF THE CRITICAL ROLE OF TREES IN URBAN AND SUBURBAN AREAS, DEMONSTRATE SPECIALIZED UNDERSTANDING OF U&CF WITHIN THEIR FOCAL AREA OF INTEREST, AND BE ABLE TO EFFECTIVELY COMMUNICATE ABOUT U&CF TO PROFESSIONALS AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC. COMPLETION OF THE CERTIFICATE WILL HELP PREPARE STUDENTS FOR CAREERS THAT PROMOTE HUMAN INTERACTIONS WITH URBAN TREES, BUILDING A STRONGER WORKFORCE IN THIS GROWING FIELD.THIS PROGRAM WILL DRAW TOGETHER EXISTING COURSES ACROSS A BROAD RANGE OF DISCIPLINES IN SEVERAL COLLEGES WITH TWO NEW COURSES REQUIRED OF ALL U&CF STUDENTS: AN INTRODUCTORY COURSE IN U&CF AND AN UPPER LEVEL CAPSTONE-INTERNSHIP EXPERIENCE. STUDENTS WILL SPECIALIZE IN ONE OF FOUR PATHWAYS ADDRESSING (1) TREES AND TREE HEALTH, (2) GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE, PLANNING, AND DESIGN, (3) ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION, AND (4) HUMAN HEALTH AND WELLNESS. TO DEVELOP AND DELIVER THIS PROGRAM, WE WILL FUND A PART-TIME PROGRAM COORDINATOR AND A PART-TIME COURSE INSTRUCTOR WHO WILL DESIGN AND INSTRUCT KEY COURSES, RECRUIT STUDENTS, AND LEAD THE U&CF CURRICULUM COMMITTEE IN PROGRAM EVALUATION AND SECURING LONG-TERM SELF-SUSTAINING FUNDING.

TO EDUCATE A NEW GENERATION OF WORKFORCE PREPARED TO LEAD SUSTAINABLE LAND RECLAMATION MANAGEMENT EFFORTS IN CENTRAL APPALACHIA, BY DEVELOPING A NEW CERTIFICATE, WHILE ENHANCING THE NUMBER AND DIVERSITY OF UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS PURSUING A UNIVERSITY DEGREE, AND INCREASING EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES FOR STUDENTS THROUGH INDUSTRY PARTNERSHIPS. AUDIENCE: STUDENTS WHO ARE ATTENDING TWO-YEAR COLLEGES AND ARE PLANNING TO PURSUE A HIGHER DEGREE AT A FOUR-YEAR UNIVERSITY. THIS WILL INCLUDE UNDERREPRESENTED AND FIRST GENERATION COLLEGE STUDENT GROUPS AND WILL ALSO TARGET STUDENTS IN EXISTING NATURAL RESOURCES AND STEM PROGRAMS, WHO WANT TO AUGMENT THEIR EDUCATION IN SUSTAINABLE LAND RECLAMATION MANAGEMENT. PRODUCTS: (1) A CERTIFICATE AND 2+2 PROGRAM IN SUSTAINABLE LAND RECLAMATION MANAGEMENT EDUCATION, (2) FIVE NEW COURSES AT WVU AND OUR PARTNER COLLEGES, AND (4) AN ONLINE COURSE LIBRARY, (5) SIX WORKSHOPS OR MEETINGS FOR FACULTY INTERACTIONS AND INDUSTRY/AGENCY PARTNERS, (6) THREE CAREER FAIRSFOR STUDENTS AND INTERACTION WITH INDUSTRY/AGENCY PARTNERS. OUTCOMES/IMPACTS: (1) A SUSTAINABLE, HIGH-QUALITY, AND MULTIDISCIPLINARY EDUCATION PROGRAM IN SUSTAINABLE LAND RECLAMATION MANAGEMENT IN THE CENTRAL APPALACHIAN REGION, (2) 10-15 TRANSFERRED STUDENTS EACH YEAR FROM TWO-YEAR COLLEGES PURSUING A BACHELOR OF SCIENCE DEGREE, (3) 35-55 STUDENTS EACH YEAR TO OBTAIN A CERTIFICATE IN SUSTAINABLE LAND RECLAMATION MANAGEMENT AT WVU, (4) HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE AND INTERNSHIPS AVAILABLE FROM REGIONAL INDUSTRY PARTNERS TO REINFORCE STUDENTS' LEARNING AND EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES.

HIGHER EDUCATION MUST DEVELOP A FOOD-SYSTEM PROFESSIONAL WORKFORCE THAT CAN TAKE ON COMPLEX FOOD SYSTEM SUSTAINABILITY CHALLENGES, VIA ADVANCED CAPACITIES FOR SYSTEMIC THOUGHT AND ACTION. FOR THIS PURPOSE, OUR PROJECT TEAM HAS RECENTLY DEVELOPED A SIGNATURE PEDAGOGY FOR THE FIELD OF SUSTAINABLE FOOD SYSTEMS (SFS). A SIGNATURE PEDAGOGY IS A CONCEPTUAL MODEL THAT GUIDES PROFESSIONAL EDUCATION IN A GIVEN FIELD. IN OUR SIGNATURE PEDAGOGY, KEY LEARNING APPROACHES ARE: (1) HOLISTIC AND PLURALISTIC (SYSTEMS) THINKING, (2) INTER- AND TRANS-DISCIPLINARITY, (3) EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING AND, (4) COLLECTIVE ACTION PROJECTS. HOWEVER, DESIGNERS OF EXISTING SFS DEGREE PROGRAMS WERE NOT FULLY COGNIZANT OF THIS MODEL, LIMITING THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THESE PROGRAMS. THE OVERALL PURPOSE OF THIS COLLABORATIVE GRANT TYPE 2 PROJECT IS TO ADDRESS THIS INSTRUCTIONAL PROBLEM BY CREATING INCLUSIVE AND REPLICABLE FOUR-YEAR CORE CURRICULA MODELS FOR BACCALAUREATE DEGREE-LEVEL SFS PROGRAMS. CURRICULUM DEVELOPMENT WILLBE GUIDED BY OUR SIGNATURE PEDAGOGY, A MODEL OF COGNITIVE MATURATION IN YOUNG ADULTS, AND METHODS FOR ENHANCING INCLUSION OF UNDER-REPRESENTED MINORITIES. DEVELOPMENT WILL PROCEED BY CORE CURRICULUM MAPPING, REFINEMENT, IMPLEMENTATION, EVALUATION, AND DISSEMINATION. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE STUDENTS AND FACULTY OF FANH AND FOOD-SYSTEMS-RELATED DEGREE PROGRAMS IN NORTH AMERICA, AND THE THREE SFS PROGRAMS PARTICIPATING IN THIS PROJECT. MAIN DELIVERABLE PRODUCTS ARE CORE SFS CURRICULUM MODELS FOR FOOD-SYSTEMS PROGRAMS AT OTHER INSTITUTIONS. THESE CURRICULUM MODELS WILL INCLUDE CURRICULUM MAPS, LESSON PLANS, HANDS-ON COURSE ACTIVITIES, AND EVALUATION TOOLS. INTENDED MEASURABLE OUTCOMES ARE: (1) EFFECTIVENESS IN MEETING LEARNING AND ENGAGEMENT OUTCOMES, (2) QUALITY OF STUDENT WORK, (3) COGNITIVE MATURATION AND, (4) PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT.

THERE IS AN URGENT NEED TO UPGRADE THE LEVEL OF TECHNOLOGY IN AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCE EDUCATION TO ADDRESS THE RAPIDLY EVOLVING INTERNET OF THINGS (IOT) WHERE UBIQUITOUS NETWORKED SENSORS WILL INFORM OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE WORLD. AS BOTH FIXED AND MOBILE SENSORS DROP IN PRICE AND INCREASE IN RELIABILITY, STUDENTS WILL NEED TO BE ABLE TO EVALUATE THE EFFICACY OF DATA THAT COMES FROM SENSOR READINGS AND TO PLAN AND USE DEPLOYMENTS OF SENSOR NETWORKS TO MAKE OPERATIONAL DECISIONS. PROJECT AUDIENCE IS FOCUSED ON UNDERGRADUATE INSTITUTIONS THAT CURRENTLY TEACH INTRODUCTORY SOIL SCIENCE COURSE AS WELL AS HISTORICALLY BLACK COLLEGES, UNIVERSITIES AND LAND GRANT TRIBAL COLLEGES THAT OFFER AGRICULTURE, NATURAL RESOURCE, OR ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE PROGRAMS. PRODUCTS OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT INCLUDE WEB-BASED LEARNING MODULES AND MOBILE APPLICATIONS FOR SOIL COLOR DETERMINATION USING A NETWORKED COLOR SENSOR. THESE MODULES WOULD TRAIN STUDENTS IN SMARTPHONE BASED SENSOR DATA COLLECTION AS WELL AS GEOSPATIAL AND CROWDSOURCING TOPICS. PROJECT DISSEMINATION WOULD BE THROUGH FREELY PROVIDED SENSOR/TABLET KITS TO A TARGETED GROUP OF UNDERGRADUATE INSTITUTIONS. WE PLAN EVALUATE AND MEASURE THE IMPACT OF THE LEARNING MODULES AND SENSOR/SMARTPHONE APPLICATIONS ON STUDENT UNDERSTANDING OF SENSOR TECHNOLOGY AND DEPLOYMENT AS WELL AS GEOSPATIAL CONCEPTS.
